ACCT 2101.Name: Principles of Accounting I
ACCT 2101.Description: A study of the underlying theory and application of financial accounting concepts. These concepts include measurement principles, financial statement preparation, and introductory financial analysis.

ACCT 2102.Name: Principles of Accounting II
ACCT 2102.Description: A study of the underlying theory and application of managerial accounting concepts. These concepts include cost measurement, decision making, budgeting, and variance analysis.

AE 1355.Name: Design Competition I
AE 1355.Description: Team-oriented aerospace systems design project directed by a faculty advisor.  Typically a national student competition in aircraft, rotorcraft, or spacecraft design. Technical role commensurate with freshman standing.

AE 1601.Name: Introduction to AE
AE 1601.Description: Overview of aerospace engineering. Common terminology, introduction to use of engineering models, professional and ethical standards and experience with team-based design of aerospace systems. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 1601 and AE 1350.

AE 2010.Name: Thermodyn&Fluids Fundam
AE 2010.Description: Thermodynamic and fluid properties. Conservation laws, Isentropic flow, shocks and expansions, introduction to flows with friction and heat transfer. Applications to aerospace devices. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 2010 and AE 3450.

AE 2010R.Name: AE 2010 Recitation
AE 2010R.Description: This recitation is an optional session in support of AE 2010. This course is designed to allow students the chance to apply their knowledge of concepts through problem solving and group discussions.

AE 2011.Name: Fluids Fundamentals
AE 2011.Description: Flowfield concepts, fluid properties, conservation equations for flows, isentropic flow, shocks and expansions, introduction to flows with friction and heat transfer. Applications to aerospace devices.

AE 2220.Name: Dynamics
AE 2220.Description: Motion of particles and mass center of bodies, kinematics and kinetics of rigid bodies in plane motion, work-energy and impulse-momentum methods, 3-D dynamics of rigid bodies.

AE 2220R.Name: AE 2220 Recitation
AE 2220R.Description: This recitation is an optional session in support of AE 2220. This course is designed to allow students the chance to apply their knowledge of concepts through problem solving and group discussions.

AE 2221.Name: 3D Dynamics
AE 2221.Description: Kinematics and kinetics of rigid bodies in three-dimensional motion.

AE 2355.Name: Design Competition II
AE 2355.Description: Team-oriented aerospace systems design project directed by a faculty advisor. Typically a national student competition in aircraft, rotorcraft, or spacecraft design.  Technical role commensurate with sophomore standing.

AE 2610.Name: Intro Exper Methods AE
AE 2610.Description: Introduction to laboratory instrumentation and measurement techniques used in aerospace. Basic application of sensor principles, uncertainty analysis, interpretation and analysis of experimental data, and documentation.

AE 2611.Name: Technical Commun for AE
AE 2611.Description: Development of technical communication skills required by aerospace engineers. Includes written, oral and visual communication methods.

AE 2698.Name: Research Assistantship
AE 2698.Description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

AE 2699.Name: Undergraduate Research
AE 2699.Description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

AE 3030.Name: Aerodynamics
AE 3030.Description: Aerodynamics of airfoils and wings in subsonic, transonic and supersonic flight. Laminar and turbulent boundary layers and effects of viscosity on aerodynamic performance.

AE 3140.Name: Structural Analysis
AE 3140.Description: Application to structural analysis. Basic equations of elasticity. Bending, shearing and torsion of thin walled structures. Energy methods for structural analysis and application to finite element theory for trusses and beam structures. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 3140 and AE 3125.

AE 3330.Name: Intro AE Vehicle Perform
AE 3330.Description: Orbital mechanics, orbit determination, and spacecraft maneuvers. Basics of airplane flight including climb, cruise, takeoff, and landing. Actuator disk theory and elements of rotorcraft performance.

AE 3355.Name: Design Competition III
AE 3355.Description: Team-oriented aerospace systems design project directed by a faculty advisor. Typically a national student competition in aircraft, rotorcraft, or spacecraft design.  Technical or leadership role commensurate with junior standing.

AE 3530.Name: Sys Dynamics&Vibration
AE 3530.Description: Modeling and analysis of lumped- and distributed-parameter systems, free and forced vibration in mechanical systems, free vibration in structural systems. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 3530 and ME 3017 or AE 3530 and AE 3515.

AE 3531.Name: Ctrl Sys Analysis&Design
AE 3531.Description: Control system performance analysis and specifications, classical methods of control system analysis and design, introduction to modern control methods. Students cannot receive credit for AE 3531 and AE 3515 or AE 3531 and ME 4452.

AE 3610.Name: Exper Fluids&Solid Mech
AE 3610.Description: Experimental laboratory in solid and fluid mechanics, aerodynamics, propulsion. Emphasis on measurement techniques, analysis and interpretation of data, comparison to analytical predictions, and reporting.

AE 4132.Name: Finite Element Analysis
AE 4132.Description: An introduction to classical approximation techniques and the fundamentals of the finite element-method applied to structures and structural dynamics with aerospace applications.

AE 4220.Name: Aeroelasticity
AE 4220.Description: Structural dynamics of one-dimensional systems. Analysis of static aeroelastic phenomena, unsteady aerodynamics, and flutter.  Equations of motion for complete aeroelastic systems; solution techniques.

AE 4311.Name: Aircraft Design I
AE 4311.Description: Conceptual design and synthesis of fixed wing aircraft.

AE 4312.Name: Aircraft Design II
AE 4312.Description: Preliminary design and synthesis of fixed wing aircraft.

AE 4321.Name: Space System Design I
AE 4321.Description: Conceptual design and synthesis of space systems. Students apply mission and spacecraft design principles.

AE 4322.Name: Space System Design II
AE 4322.Description: Advanced design applications of space systems. Students apply mission and spacecraft design principles.

AE 4331.Name: Rotorcraft Design I
AE 4331.Description: Conceptual design of traditional, urban air mobility, unmanned rotorcraft vehicles.

AE 4332.Name: Rotorcraft Design II
AE 4332.Description: Preliminary design of traditional, urban air mobility, unmanned rotorcraft vehicles.

AE 4355.Name: Design Competition IV
AE 4355.Description: Team-oriented aerospace systems design project directed by a faculty advisor.  Typically a national student competition in aircraft, rotorcraft, or spacecraft design. Technical or leadership role commensurate with senior standing.

AE 4361.Name: Space Flight Operations
AE 4361.Description: This course introduces the foundations and analysis of space flight operations for human and robotic space missions.

AE 4451.Name: Jet & Rocket Propulsion
AE 4451.Description: Principles of aerospace propulsion systems. Thermodynamic cycles. Thermodynamics of combustion. Turbine engine and rocket performance characteristics. Cycle/component analysis of engines and turbomachinery.

AE 4531.Name: Aircraft Flight Dynamics
AE 4531.Description: Three-dimensional rigid body dynamics, aircraft equations of motion, static and dynamic stability, flight control design, introduction to aeroelastic phenomena. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 4531 and AE 3521.

AE 4532.Name: Spacecraft Flight Dynam
AE 4532.Description: Cover fundamental material in orbit and attitude dynamics. Investigate orbits, rendezvous/intercept maneuvers, interplanetary transfers, attitude coordinates, attitude stability, attitude control, and attitude estimation. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 4532 and AE 4310.

AE 4610.Name: Dynamics & Control Lab
AE 4610.Description: Experiments in dynamics and control related to aerospace engineering topics.

AE 4698.Name: Research Assistantship
AE 4698.Description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

AE 4699.Name: Undergraduate Research
AE 4699.Description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

AE 4793.Name: Composite Mater& Process
AE 4793.Description: Basic principles of selection and design of composite materials and their manufacturing and testing. Cost factors. Laboratory exercises on manufacturing and tests. Crosslisted with CEE, CHE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 4793.

AE 6012.Name: Turbulent Flows
AE 6012.Description: Basic characteristics of turbulence.  Statistical methods. Reynolds averaging, kinetic energy budget, and scaling issues.  Homogeneity and isotrophy.  Free and wall bounded shear flows. Simulation and modeling.

AE 6015.Name: Advanced Aerodynamics
AE 6015.Description: Introduce concepts, derivation and application of aerodynamic fundamentals. Emphasis on advanced knowledge in analysis and design of fixed-wing, launch/atmospheric return vehicles, and rotating systems.

AE 6042.Name: Computational Fluid Dyn
AE 6042.Description: Finite-difference, finite volume methods for solution of Navier-Stokes and Euler equations. Classification of equations, stability, grids, boundary conditions, implicit and explicit methods, turbulence modeling.

AE 6050.Name: Gas Dynamics
AE 6050.Description: Defining equations for compressible flows, real gas properties and their effect on the behavior of equilibrium and non-equilibrium flows.

AE 6115.Name: Fndmntl Aero Struct Anal
AE 6115.Description: Overview and fundamentals of aerospace structural analysis, including virtual work and energy methods, buckling and advanced structural theories.

AE 6200.Name: Aeroelasticity
AE 6200.Description: Understanding and analysis of aeroelastic phenomena in fixed-wing aircraft, static aeroelasticity, dynamic aeroelasticity, and dynamic response and transient stresses in aircraft structures.

AE 6210.Name: Advanced Dynamics I
AE 6210.Description: Kinematics of particles and rigid bodies, angular velocity, inertia properties, holonomic and nonholonomic constraints, generalized forces.

AE 6310.Name: Optimiz Design Engin Sys
AE 6310.Description: Introduction to optimization problem formulations for engineering design, algorithms for constrained nonlinear programming, multiobjective and multidisciplinary optimization, and robust design optimization.

AE 6334.Name: Rotorcraft Design II
AE 6334.Description: Students work together on this application to complete the preliminary design stage of a specific rotorcraft. Participants are exposed to disciplinary and interdisciplinary issues.

AE 6344.Name: Aircraft Design II
AE 6344.Description: Students work together on this application to complete the preliminary design stage of a specific aircraft or missile. Participants are exposed to disciplinary and interdisciplinary issues.

AE 6353.Name: Orbital Mechanics
AE 6353.Description: First graduate-level astrodynamics class that includes two-body orbital mechanics, orbit determination, orbit prediction, orbital maneuvers, lunar and interplanetary trajectories, orbital rendzvous and space navigation.

AE 6357.Name: Satellite Orbit Determ
AE 6357.Description: Satellite Orbit Determination is a graduate-level course designed to provide the theoretical and practical knowledge to estimate the position of a satellite from tracking measurements.

AE 6361.Name: Propulsion Sys Design I
AE 6361.Description: Air breathing propulsion design with emphasis on multidisciplinary design issues related to system integration, cycle selection, performance, cost, reliability, maintainability, etc.

AE 6394.Name: Sys of Sys Eng App
AE 6394.Description: Application of developed System of Systems analysis frameworks for the performance of Grand Challenge projects.

AE 6450.Name: Rocket Propulsion
AE 6450.Description: Analysis and design of rocket engines including liquid, solid, hybrid, and advanced propulsion systems.

AE 6520.Name: Adv Flight Dynamics
AE 6520.Description: Reference frames and transformations, general equations of unsteady motion, application to fixed-wing, rotary-wing and space vehicles, stability characteristics, flight in turbulent atmosphere.

AE 6580.Name: Nonlinear Control
AE 6580.Description: Advanced treatment of nonlinear robust control. Lyapunov stability theory, absolute stability, dissipativity, feedback linearization, Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman theory, nonlinear H-infinity, backstepping control, and control Lyapunov functions.

AE 6701.Name: Wind Engineering
AE 6701.Description: An introductory course on wind energy and its potential; modeling and design of wind turbines; analysis of the economic benefits of wind turbine systems. Credit will not be awarded for both AE 6701 and ME 6701.

AE 6761.Name: Acoustics II
AE 6761.Description: Radiation and scattering of sound waves in fluids, duct acoustics, dissipation phenomena. Crosslisted with ME 6761.

AE 6766.Name: Combustion
AE 6766.Description: Introductory chemical kinetics, detonations and deflagrations, laminar flame propagation in premixed gases, ignition and quenching, laminar diffusion flames and droplet burning, turbulent reacting flows. Crosslisted with ME 6766.

AE 6769.Name: Linear Elasticity
AE 6769.Description: Governing equations of linear elasticity, plane elasticity, boundary value problems, airy stress function and complex variable methods, simple three-dimensional solutions. Crosslisted with ME 6769.

AE 7742.Name: Robo Pro Prep 2
AE 7742.Description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Selecting and applying for Internship. Developing capstone project proposal. Public speaking practice and preparation.

AE 7772.Name: Fund-Fracture Mechanics
AE 7772.Description: Advanced study of failure of structural materials under load, mechanics of fracture, and microscopic and macroscopic aspects of the fracture of engineering materials. Crosslisted with CHE, CEE, ME, and MSE 7772.

AE 7774.Name: Fatigue-Materials&Struct
AE 7774.Description: Mechanical and microstructural aspects of nucleation and growth of cracks under cyclic loading conditions, notch effects, cumulative damage, multiaxial loading, and fatigue crack propagation. Crosslisted with CEE, CHE, ME, and MSE 7774.

AE 7785.Name: Intro Robotics Research
AE 7785.Description: Familiarizes students with the core areas of robotics; mechanics, control, perception, AI, and autonomy. Provides an introduction to the mathematical tools required in robotics research.

AE 8002.Name: AE Graduate Seminar
AE 8002.Description: Introduce AE graduate students to world-class aerospace researchers and topics, discuss and demonstrate basic graduate student resources and skills.

AE 8741.Name: Robo Capstone Project
AE 8741.Description: Teams or individuals apply the knowledge and skills acquired throughout the MS program to a faculty supervised robotics project.

AE 8750.Name: Robotics Research Fnd I
AE 8750.Description: Multidisciplinary research course supervised by two robotics faculty from different schools participating in the robotics Ph.D. program.

AE 8751.Name: Robotics Research Fnd II
AE 8751.Description: Continuation of AE 8751 (Robotics Research Foundation I).

AE 8997.Name: Teaching Assistantship
AE 8997.Description: For graduate students holding graduate teaching assistantships.

AS 1000.Name: Air Force Leadership-Lab
AS 1000.Description: Air Force customs and courtesies, drill and ceremonies, and introduction to the military environment. Emphasis on developing the leadership and interpersonal skills needed of Air Force officers.

AS 1120.Name: Heritage & Vlus of AFII
AS 1120.Description: A survey course designed to introduce students to the Department of the Air Force (DAF) and provides an overview of the basic characteristics, missions, communications and organization of the Air and Space Forces. Topics include: What is War?, Principles of War and Tenets of Airpower, and What the Department of the Air Force Brings to the Fight. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

AS 2220.Name: US Air & Space Power II
AS 2220.Description: This course provides a fundamental understanding of both leadership and team building. The lessons and course flow are designed to prepare students for field training and leadership positions in the detachment. Topics include: Human Relations, Conflict Management, and Stress Management and Resiliency. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

AS 3320.Name: Leading Ppl & Eff Comm II
AS 3320.Description: This course utilizes student’s field training experience to take a more in-depth look at leadership. Special emphasis is placed on enhancing communication skills, and why that is important as a leader. Students have an opportunity to try out these leadership and management techniques in a supervised environment as juniors and seniors. Topics include: Mentoring, Ethical Decision Making, and Establishing Expectations. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

AS 4420.Name: Na Sec & Prep Act Dty II
AS 4420.Description: This course is designed for college seniors and provides them the foundation to understand their role as military officers and how they are directly tied to our National Security Strategy. It is an overview of the complex social and political issues facing the military profession and requires a measure of sophistication commensurate with the senior college level. Topics include: Leadership Authority and Responsibility, Military Justice, and Airmen Comprehensive Assessment. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

APPH 1040.Name: Sci Foundation of Health
APPH 1040.Description: Students will learn how genetics, the environment and human behavior influence well-being.  Topics include health fitness, immunity, nutrition, stress management and chronic disease prevention. Credit not allowed for both APPH 1040 and APPH 1050 or HPS 1040 or APPH 1060.

APPH 1050.Name: Sci of Phys Act & Health
APPH 1050.Description: Students will learn the importance of health fitness, good nutrition, stress management and chronic disease prevention.  Activity portion of course will focus on training to improve fitness.  Credit not allowed for both APPH 1050 and HPS 1040 or APPH 1040 or APPH 1060.

APPH 1060.Name: Flourish Str Well & Res
APPH 1060.Description: This course is designed to help students improve their health/well-being and flourish by using conceptual pillars such as coping, resiliency, optimism, mindfulness, and emotional intelligence. Credit not awarded for both APPH 1060 and APPH 1040 or APPH 1050.

APPH 6233.Name: Aging Movement Control
APPH 6233.Description: The aim of this course is to review research literature dealing with the effects of advances in age on the CNS and motor performance.

APPH 6241.Name: Neuromotor Physiology
APPH 6241.Description: The course will focus on function and adaptations of the skeletal, muscular and neural systems. Interactions among various systems and their plasticity will be emphasized.

APPH 6400.Name: Human Neuroanatomy
APPH 6400.Description: The purpose of this course is to learn the anatomical makeup of the human nervous system.  In this course we will closely examine details of central and peripheral neuroanatomy with links to function.  As well, comparisons with non-human vertebrate neuroanatomy will be made.

ASE 6003.Name: Modeling/Sim Sys Eng
ASE 6003.Description: Introduction to modeling and simulation for systems engineers.  Topics include problem formulation, conceptual modeling, simulation methodologies, verification and validation, DOE, simulation execution, and output analysis.

ASE 6102.Name: System of Systems & Arch
ASE 6102.Description: Develop a broader understanding of the interdependencies and interoperability issues, interfaces, and processes for creating and defining Systems Architecture for complex systems.

ASE 6103.Name: System Lifecycle & Integ
ASE 6103.Description: System preliminary design must address product and process design throughout system lifecycle from integration through manufacturing to phase-out along with interfaces to other emerging systems.

ARBC 1002.Name: Elementary Arabic II
ARBC 1002.Description: This is a course continuation of Arabic I.

ARBC 2002.Name: Intermediate Arabic II
ARBC 2002.Description: This course is a continuation of ARBC 2001.

ARBC 3420.Name: Introduction to Africa
ARBC 3420.Description: This interdisciplinary course will use a variety of approaches to study significant aspects of contemporary Africa’s societies, cultures, and representations. Taught in English.

ARBC 3501.Name: Men-Women In Islam
ARBC 3501.Description: The course discusses contemporary Arab women and men writers' interpretation of the Qur'an demonstrating the egalitarian and anti-patriarchal nature of its teachings. Taught in English.

ARCH 1017.Name: Architecture Studio 1
ARCH 1017.Description: Introduction to the design of complex problems through an emphasis on integrative and collaborative design strategies, research , critical reflection, and interdisciplinary teamwork.

ARCH 2017.Name: Architecture Studio 3
ARCH 2017.Description: Elementary design exercises focusing upon the compositional integration of building and site through the creative assimilation of programmatic, technical, and contextual requirements.

ARCH 2112.Name: History of Arch II
ARCH 2112.Description: Architectural history during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries emphasizing buildings in their cultural context as informed by social, technological, and constructive factors and theoretical positions.

ARCH 3017.Name: Architecture Studio 5
ARCH 3017.Description: Intermediate architectural design projects exploring the inter-relationships of various programmatic models, normative building types, and technological themes within specific physical, urban and cultural contexts.

ARCH 3200.Name: Portfolio Design
ARCH 3200.Description: Explores strategies of descriptions, representation, and presentation and other art-related ideas in order to communicate design work and design speculation effectively.

ARCH 4015.Name: Structures 1
ARCH 4015.Description: Gravity loads on building structures.  Introduction to structural planning.  Design of wood and steel structures.  Properties of wood and architectural metals.  Computer-based analysis of structures.

ARCH 4017.Name: Architecture Studio 7
ARCH 4017.Description: Advanced studies in architectural design emphasizing application of analytical, conceptual, and representational skills within projects that engage and problematize urban context culturally, ecologically and technologically. Capstone Design Studio.

ARCH 4107.Name: Intro to Historic Preser
ARCH 4107.Description: This course provides an overview of the history, philosophy, organization, current legislation, policies, and practice of historic preservation.

ARCH 4109.Name: Arch and Minimalism
ARCH 4109.Description: This course examines the influence of "minimalism," the 1960s art phenomenon, upon architecture culture and production from 1968-present.

ARCH 4127.Name: Intro to Art & Arch in Italy
ARCH 4127.Description: Required preparation for the COA Summer Program in Italy.  The course includes the fundamentals of art and architecture,  basic Italian language skills, and  library research for required summer program projects.

ARCH 4447.Name: Urban Ecological Design
ARCH 4447.Description: This course engages the contemporary issues of urban ecology and its articulation to design. It explores relationship between urban forms and flows of ecology, energy, material, water and information. Credit will not be awarded for both ARCH 4447 and ARCH 6447 or ARCH 4447 and CP 6836.

ARCH 4699.Name: Undergraduate Research
ARCH 4699.Description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

ARCH 4823.Name: Arch & Decolonization
ARCH 4823.Description: Special Topics in History and Theory Prerequisite: consent of the College. Topics in advanced areas of history and theory of architecture.

ARCH 4833.Name: Technological Craft
ARCH 4833.Description: Special Topics in Technology Prerequisite: consent of the College.

ARCH 6015.Name: Structures 1
ARCH 6015.Description: This course provides students with a basic knowledge of analysis and design of building structures and the ordering of structural systems to resist gravity and lateral loads.

ARCH 6029.Name: Core 2 Studio
ARCH 6029.Description: Intermediate studies in architectural design emphasizing integrative design strategies that engage the programmatic, contextual, and constructed dimensions of architecture and its representations.

ARCH 6040.Name: Advanced Studio 2
ARCH 6040.Description: Architectural design studio exploring advanced issues in architecture from the perspectives of professional practice, sustainability, technology and urban design

ARCH 6050.Name: Design + Research Studio 2
ARCH 6050.Description: Advanced architectural design emphasizing innovation through applied research. Emerging methods of design generation/evaluation. Changing topics: healthcare, fabrication, urbanism, ecology, building performance, cultural institutions.

ARCH 6100.Name: Retrofitting Suburbia
ARCH 6100.Description: Study of suburban redevelopment trends, projects, and policies that improve environmental, social, and economic sustainability, with an emphasis on urban design strategies.

ARCH 6106.Name: Arch History II
ARCH 6106.Description: Architectural history during the 19th and 20th centuries emphasizing buildings in their cultural context as informed by social, technological, and constructive factors and theoretical positions.  Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6106 and ARCH 4106 or ARCH 2112.

ARCH 6107.Name: Intro to Historic Preser
ARCH 6107.Description: This course provides an overview of the history, philosophy, organization, current legislation, policies, and practice of historic preservation.

ARCH 6109.Name: Arch and Minimalism
ARCH 6109.Description: This course examines the influence of "minimalism," the 1960s art phenomenon, upon architecture culture and production from 1968-present.

ARCH 6127.Name: Intro-Art& Arch in Italy
ARCH 6127.Description: Required preparation for the COA Summer Program in Italy.  Includes the fundamentals of art and architecture; basic Italian language skills; library research for required summer program projects.

ARCH 6151.Name: Theories of Urban Design
ARCH 6151.Description: Contemporary theories of urban design and their relationship to the contemporary city examined through architects' writings, urban projects, and interdisciplinary criticism.

ARCH 6210.Name: Architectonics
ARCH 6210.Description: The study of architecture of form from both an historical and a mathematical perspective.  The formal theory is applied mathematics, group theory, combinatroics, as well as recent studies in the history of mathematics.

ARCH 6312.Name: Ecological Practice
ARCH 6312.Description: An historically and culturally grounded examination of the ecological perspective. Critical and productive engagement with green guidelines, laws, products, design briefs, and procedures.

ARCH 6316.Name: Practice of Arch 2
ARCH 6316.Description: Methods of architectural project delivery and project management.  Fundamentals of building economics.  Emergent models of research-driven architectural practice.

ARCH 6352.Name: Theory of Architecture 2
ARCH 6352.Description: Approaches to architectural form, style, and tectonics from aesthetic, social, and technological perspectives.  Instrumental and symbolic uses of architectural media in design and building production.

ARCH 6447.Name: Urban Ecological Design
ARCH 6447.Description: This course engages the contemporary issues of urban ecology and its articulation to design.  It explores relationship between urban forms and flows of ecology, energy, material, water and information.  Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6447 and CP 6836.

ARCH 6503.Name: BIM Applications
ARCH 6503.Description: Survey of Building Information Modeling - its technologies exploration of new technologies to be applied and new procedures of project execution.

ARCH 7014.Name: Urban Design Studio 2
ARCH 7014.Description: Advanced urban design problems emphasizing the application of contemporary urban design research and multidisciplinary collaboration into the design process.

ARCH 7030.Name: Media + Modeling 3
ARCH 7030.Description: Advanced approaches to two and three dimensional modeling and representation in architecture using both manual and digital media and techniques.

ARCH 7102.Name: Integr Bldg Syst II
ARCH 7102.Description: Approaches building design and systems integration through the making of construction drawings and specifications of metal frame buildings, including structural steel calculations.

ARCH 7151.Name: History of Urban Form
ARCH 7151.Description: History of the city as a collective work of architecture with an emphasis on the city's physical form and space.

ARCH 7350.Name: Found of Arch Theory
ARCH 7350.Description: Reviews thought and attitudes guiding architecture since the modern movement, their philosophical sources, and their relationship with architectural production. Defines architectural theory.

ARCH 7360.Name: Design & Climate Change
ARCH 7360.Description: This course positions design as an essential component of research that explores the sociocultural and eco-political dimensions of climate change as it applies to the built environment.

ARCH 7625.Name: Theories of Inquiry
ARCH 7625.Description: Introduction to research paradigms and their assumptions. The formulation of questions and frameworks of description, representation, analysis, interpretation, and data control.

ARCH 8630.Name: Architecture Space & Culture
ARCH 8630.Description: Accounts of the social functions of architectural space and associated design choices, across a variety of building types and scales of environmental design.

ARCH 8799.Name: Qualifying Paper
ARCH 8799.Description: Preparation for Qualifying Paper in Doctorial Program in Architecture

ARCH 8997.Name: Teaching Assistantship
ARCH 8997.Description: For graduate students holding graduate teaching assistantships.

ARCH 8998.Name: Research Assistantship
ARCH 8998.Description: For gratuate students holding graduate research assistantships.

BIOS 1107.Name: Principles of Biology I
BIOS 1107.Description: Lecture part of a sequence designed for science majors. An introduction to biological principles, including biomacromolecules, bioenergetics, cell structure, genetics, evolution, and ecological relationships for STEM majors and prehealth students.

BIOS 1107L.Name: Principles of Biology Lab
BIOS 1107L.Description: Laboratory exercises supplement the lecture material of BIOL 1107. A laboratory-based introduction to biological principles, including biomacromolecules, bioenergetics, cell structure, genetics, evolution, and ecological relationships for STEM majors and prehealth students.

BIOS 1108.Name: Principles of Biology II
BIOS 1108.Description: Lecture part of a sequence designed for science majors. An introduction to organ and organismal biology, emphasizing physiological processes, growth/development, and biodiversity from an evolutionary perspective for STEM majors and prehealth students.

BIOS 1108L.Name: Principles of Biology II Lab
BIOS 1108L.Description: Laboratory exercises supplement the lecture material of BIOL 1108. A laboratory-based introduction to organ and organismal biology, emphasizing physiological processes, growth/development, and biodiversity from an evolutionary perspective for STEM majors and prehealth students.

BIOS 1208.Name: Majors Organismal Biol
BIOS 1208.Description: An introduction to biology at the organ and organismal level, with emphasis on physiological processes, integration of growth and development, and biodiversity from an evolutionary perspective.

BIOS 1208L.Name: Organismal Biol Proj Lab
BIOS 1208L.Description: A project-based laboratory introduction to biology at the organ and organismal level, with emphasis on physiological processes, integration of growth and development, and biodiversity from an evolutionary perspective.

BIOS 1220.Name: Biology of Sex & Death
BIOS 1220.Description: Students learn biology through the lens of the formation and collapse of biological systems, organized around questions pertaining to life, sex, and death.

BIOS 1220R.Name: Biology of Sex and Death Recit
BIOS 1220R.Description: A recitation period for BIOS 1220, an introduction to biology and scientific methodology organized around questions pertaining to life, sex, and death.

BIOS 2300.Name: Ecology
BIOS 2300.Description: Introduction to ecological processes at individual, population, and community levels that occur in plant, animal, and microbial taxa, and their relevance to current environmental problems.

BIOS 2301.Name: Ecology Lab
BIOS 2301.Description: The companion laboratory for BIOS 2300 (Ecology). This course stresses understanding ecological concepts through a combination of lab and field experiments, and computer simulations.

BIOS 2600.Name: Genetics
BIOS 2600.Description: Mendelian and molecular genetics: principles of inheritance, gene structure and function, foundations of recombinant DNA technology, genetic basis of variation and evolution.

BIOS 2601.Name: Genetics Laboratory
BIOS 2601.Description: A laboratory course in fundamental techniques of genetic analysis.

BIOS 3380.Name: Microbiology
BIOS 3380.Description: Basic biology of bacteria, fungi, algae, and viruses, with emphasis on bacteriology

BIOS 3400.Name: Mathematical Models in Biology
BIOS 3400.Description: Probability and deterministic models in biology, including discrete and continuous probability distributions and dynamic models from molecular and cellular biology to ecology and epidemiology.

BIOS 3450.Name: Cell Molecular Biol
BIOS 3450.Description: An introduction to the structure and function of cells and their organelles with emphasis on eucaryotic cellular and molecular processes.

BIOS 3600.Name: Evolutionary Biology
BIOS 3600.Description: A comprehensive overview of evolutionary biology, including processes (e.g., natural selection, genetic drift) and resulting patterns (e.g., genome organization, phylogeny, and the fossil record).

BIOS 3753.Name: Human Anatomy
BIOS 3753.Description: Detailed study of human body structures using a regional and systems approach.  Emphasis is placed on structural relationships and the integration of body systems.

BIOS 3755.Name: Human Physiology
BIOS 3755.Description: Students will explore the function and adaptation of the human body emphasizing neuromuscular, cardio-respiratory, gastrointestinal, endocrine, and urinary systems to maintain homeostasis and human health.

BIOS 3756.Name: Physiology Lab
BIOS 3756.Description: Course focuses on non-invasive human experiments supplemented with in vitro tissues experiments to explore fundamental physiological concepts and learn basic methods of physiological measurements

BIOS 4100.Name: Exercise Physiology
BIOS 4100.Description: Physiology of human movement with emphasis on metabolic, cardiorespiratory, and musculoskeletal aspects; associated topics include body composition, thermoregulation, and ergogenic aids.

BIOS 4221.Name: Biological Oceanography
BIOS 4221.Description: An introduction to the major biological processes in the ocean including primary production, elemental cycling, food webs, and fisheries.

BIOS 4401.Name: Exper Dgn &Statis Methods
BIOS 4401.Description: Introductory course on experimental design, hypothesis testing and basic statistical techniques commonly applied in biosciences research. Exercises based on statistical software packages.

BIOS 4410.Name: Microbial Ecology
BIOS 4410.Description: Advanced studies of microbial ecosystems, the specific roles of bacteria in maintaining ecological balance, and the evolution of the ecosystem in response to changing environments.

BIOS 4417.Name: Marine Ecology
BIOS 4417.Description: An overview of the physical forces and biotic interactions structuring marine communities and of the major threats to these communities

BIOS 4418.Name: Microbial Physiology
BIOS 4418.Description: Study of the physiology of growth and metabolic activities of microorganisms.

BIOS 4432.Name: Conservation Biology
BIOS 4432.Description: This course explores the broad diversity of disciplines in conservation, with emphasis on biological phenomena. Analyzes contemporary issues affecting biodiversity, extinction risk, and policymaking.

BIOS 4440.Name: Human Pathology
BIOS 4440.Description: The course provides a comprehensive overview of clinical human anatomic pathology. The course will focus on select diseases and their etiologies, pathogenesis, morphological changes, and clinical manifestations.

BIOS 4460.Name: Comm Biologicl Research
BIOS 4460.Description: Students learn to convey the importance of research findings in the biological sciences and to critically evaluate research results through discussions and scientific presentations.

BIOS 4471.Name: Behavioral Biology
BIOS 4471.Description: An introduction to the study of the principles of behavior of all kinds of organisms, from microbes to mammals.

BIOS 4510.Name: Epigenetics
BIOS 4510.Description: This course will introduce the basic concepts and mechanisms in epigenetics, covering topics ranging from stem cell reprogramming, organismal development, social behaviors, to human diseases.

BIOS 4515.Name: Community Ecology
BIOS 4515.Description: An advanced ecology course that covers classic and contemporary concepts, patterns, and processes in the field of community ecology.

BIOS 4520.Name: Health Genes Society
BIOS 4520.Description: Capstone project based investigation of the roles that genes and culture play in shaping health, including an introduction to personalized medicine.

BIOS 4565.Name: Chromosome Bio & Disease
BIOS 4565.Description: This course explores the fundamental mechanisms governing metabolism of eukaryotic chromosomes and human diseases resulting from malfunctioning of chromosomal maintenance.

BIOS 4570.Name: Immunology
BIOS 4570.Description: A survey of modern immunology and its applications

BIOS 4590.Name: Research Project Lab
BIOS 4590.Description: Experience in designing, implementing, and communicating a biology research project, and practical training in modern approaches for biological research.

BIOS 4607.Name: Molecular Microbiology
BIOS 4607.Description: Molecular genetics of bacteria with an emphasis on experimental approaches, regulatory mechanisms on disease-causing and environmental bacteria, and biotechnology applications derived from microbes.

BIOS 4651.Name: Bioethics
BIOS 4651.Description: This course examines important bioethical issues in research, policy, medicine, and the environment in light of ethical theory and the process of scientific inquiry.

BIOS 4690.Name: Independnt Research Proj
BIOS 4690.Description: Independent research with proposal and manuscript writing, conducted with the guidance of a faculty member.

BIOS 4694.Name: Intern Assistantship
BIOS 4694.Description: Biology Undergraduate Internship for pay for juniors and seniors, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Biology.

BIOS 4695.Name: Undergraduate Internship
BIOS 4695.Description: Biology Undergraduate Internship for credit for juniors and seniors, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Biology.

BIOS 4696.Name: Biol Teaching Assistant
BIOS 4696.Description: Biology teaching carried out under the guidance of a faculty member.

BIOS 4697.Name: Biol Undergrad Teaching
BIOS 4697.Description: An introduction to teaching biology for undergraduate teaching assistants, with a focus on effective teaching, active engagement of students, and development of innovative classroom activities.

BIOS 4698.Name: Research Assistantship
BIOS 4698.Description: Undergraduate research under the guidance of a faculty member for juniors and seniors.

BIOS 4699.Name: Undergraduate Research
BIOS 4699.Description: Undergraduate research under the guidance of a faculty member for juniors and seniors.

BIOS 4802.Name: Seminal Papers in Astrobiology
BIOS 4802.Description: Special Topics in the School of Biological Sciences.

BIOL 6410.Name: Microbial Ecology
BIOL 6410.Description: Advanced studies of microbial ecosystems, the specific roles of bacteria in maintaining ecological balance, and the evolution of the ecosystem in response to changing environments.

BIOL 6417.Name: Marine Ecology
BIOL 6417.Description: An overview of the ecological and evolutionary patterns, processes, and mechanisms affecting the organization, structure, and function of a broad variety of marine communities.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL 6417 and BIOL 4417.

BIOL 6418.Name: Microbial Physiology
BIOL 6418.Description: Study of the physiology of growth and metabolic activities of microorganisms.

BIOL 6600.Name: Evolution
BIOL 6600.Description: An introduction to evolutionary patterns and processes, including the history of life, phylogenetics, population genetics, quantitative genetics, molecular evolution, and other important topics in evolutionary biology.

BIOL 6607.Name: Molecular Microbiology
BIOL 6607.Description: Molecular genetics of bacteria with an emphasis on experimental approaches, regulatory mechanisms in disease-causing and environmental bacteria, and biotechnology applications derived from microbes. Credit will not be awarded for both BIOL 6607 and BIOL 4607, BIOL 4608, or BIOL 6608.

BIOL 7210.Name: Computational Genomics
BIOL 7210.Description: In this active learning class, students will learn to convert sequence information into knowledge through the use of computational genomics tools, applications and databases.

BIOL 8003.Name: Seminar
BIOL 8003.Description: Weekly seminars on current research presented by various scientists in the field of biology.

BIOL 8061.Name: Curr Research In Qbios
BIOL 8061.Description: The overall objective of the course is to enable QBioS PhD students to attend seminars on advances across all areas of the life sciences, including those by 4th year QBioS students.

BIOL 8510.Name: Epigenetics
BIOL 8510.Description: This course will introduce the basic concepts and mechanisms in epigenetics, covering topics ranging from stem cell reprogramming, organismal development, social behaviors, to human diseases.

BIOL 8515.Name: Community Ecology
BIOL 8515.Description: An advanced ecology course that covers classic and contemporary concepts, patterns, and processes in the field of community ecology

BIOL 8802.Name: Seminal Papers in Astrobiology
BIOL 8802.Description: New graduate lecture courses in areas of current interest.

BIOL 8901.Name: Special Problems
BIOL 8901.Description: Research problems in biology under the supervision of a faculty member.

BIOL 8902.Name: Special Problems
BIOL 8902.Description: Research problems in biology under the supervision of a faculty member.

BIOL 8997.Name: Teaching Assistantship
BIOL 8997.Description: For graduate students holding a teaching assistantship.

BIOL 8998.Name: Research Assistantship
BIOL 8998.Description: For graduate students holding research assistantships.

BMEJ 9999.Name: GT-PKU
BMEJ 9999.Description: For GT, PKU, and Emory students during terms when they are not taking other GT courses.  Placeholder course.

BMED 1000.Name: Intro to Biomedical Engr
BMED 1000.Description: An introduction to the field of biomedical engineering, with an emphasis on career preparation.

BMED 2110.Name: Conservation Prin in BME
BMED 2110.Description: A study of material and energy balances applied to problems in biomedical engineering.

BMED 2250.Name: Problems in Biomed Engr
BMED 2250.Description: Biomedical engineering problems from industrial and clinical applications are addressed and solved in small groups using problem-based learning methodologies. Credit will not be awarded for both BMED 2250 and BMED 1300.

BMED 2310.Name: Intro Biomed Engr Design
BMED 2310.Description: In small teams students will apply problem-based learning and human centered design to reverse engineer, analyze, and redesign medical devices. Credit will not be awareded for both BMED 2310 and BMED 2300.

BMED 2400.Name: Intro-Bioengr Stats
BMED 2400.Description: Introduction to statistical modeling and data analysis in bioscientific and bioengineering applications. Topics include estimation, testing, regression, and experimental design.

BMED 3100.Name: Systems Physiology
BMED 3100.Description: An introduction to human physiology emphasizing biomedical engineering aproaches to the understanding of basic organ function, disease states, and medical intervention.

BMED 3110.Name: Quant Engr Physio Lab I
BMED 3110.Description: A hands-on lab providing an active learning team environment to reinforce selected engineering principles of physiology, emphasizing a quantitative model-oriented approach to physiological systems.

BMED 3310.Name: Biotransport
BMED 3310.Description: Fundamental principles of fluid, heat, and mass transfer with particular emphasis on physiological and biomedical systems. Credit will not be awarded for both BMED 3310 and BMED 3300.

BMED 3410.Name: Intro to Biomechanics
BMED 3410.Description: Introduces concepts and approaches for biomedical deformation and dynamics problems using the application of simple models from statics, mechanics of materials, kinematics, and dynamics.

BMED 3520.Name: Biomed Sys & Modeling
BMED 3520.Description: Introduction of computational systems biology, including the modeling process, various types of models, standard analysis and simulation of systems, and applications in real-world biological systems. Credit will not be awarded for both BMED 3520 and BMED 3510.

BMED 3600.Name: Physio Cell & Mol  Syst
BMED 3600.Description: In depth cell and molecular physiology focused on cellular responses to stimuli, including cell organization/ reorganization, membrane transport/kinetics, cell signaling/ molecular biology, mechanobiology and energy requirements.

BMED 3610.Name: Quant Engr Physio Lab II
BMED 3610.Description: This lab provides an active learning team environment, incorporating common cell/molecular biology techniques, to reinforce selected engineering principles in an in vitro cell culture setting.

BMED 4000.Name: Art of Tell Your Story
BMED 4000.Description: Students will create a professional portfolio and develop the ability to pitch themselves to an audience to prepare themselves to begin their professional careers

BMED 4602.Name: Capstone Design
BMED 4602.Description: Team-oriented design project in biomedical engineering, incorporating engineering standards and realistic design constraints.  Includes introduction to relevant regulatory, intellectual property, and business management topics.

BMED 4603.Name: Advanced Design
BMED 4603.Description: Continuation of a team-oriented design experience initiated in BMED 4602 Capstone Design.  Includes more advanced relevant regulatory. intellectual property, and business management topics.  Credit not allowed for both BMED 4603 and BMED 4600 (or BMED 4601).

BMED 4698.Name: Research Assistantship
BMED 4698.Description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BMED 4699.Name: Undergraduate Research
BMED 4699.Description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BMED 4723.Name: Interdis Capstone Design
BMED 4723.Description: Interdisciplinary Capstone Design, Industry projects or CREATE-X section.

BMED 4751.Name: Intro to Biomaterials
BMED 4751.Description: Introduction to different classes of biomaterials (polymers, metals, ceramics) and physiological responses to biomaterial implantation. Topics include material properties, host response, and biomaterial characterization techniques. Crosslisted with MSE 4751.

BMED 4758.Name: Biosolid Mechanics
BMED 4758.Description: The mechanics of living tissue, e.g., arteries, skin, heart muscle, ligament, tendon, cartilage, and bone. Constitutive equations and some simple mechanical models. Mechanics of cells.  Applications. Crosslisted with AE, CHE, and ME 4758.

BMED 4765.Name: Drug Design,Devlpmnt&Delivery
BMED 4765.Description: Introduction to the pharmaceutical development process, including design of new drugs, synthesis and manufacturing issues, and methods for delivery into the body. Includes student presentations. Crosslisted with CHEM and CHBE 4765.

BMED 4775.Name: Trans Microsystems
BMED 4775.Description: Learn how to design biomedical microsystems ready for clinical and biomedical translation. Course blends theory with examples of successful biomedical research, clinical translation, and case studies.

BMED 4782.Name: Biosystems Analysis
BMED 4782.Description: Analytical methods for modeling biological systems, including white-noise protocols for characterizing nonlinear systems. Crosslisted with CHE, ECE, and ME 4782.

BMED 4813.Name: Clin Observ Design Exp
BMED 4813.Description: Courses in special topics of current interest not included in the regular course offerings.

BMED 4823.Name: Clin Observ Design Exp
BMED 4823.Description: Courses in special topics of current interest not included in the regular course offerings.

BMED 6210.Name: Magnetic Resonance Imag
BMED 6210.Description: This course covers the basic physics and engineering principles, advanced techniques and major applications of magnetic resonance imaging.

BMED 6504.Name: Fina Planning for Projs
BMED 6504.Description: Finance planning for development projects including: costing, forecasting, time value of money, breakeven analysis, return on investment analysis, capital budgeting, risk and return, working capital management.

BMED 6508.Name: BioID Masters Project I
BMED 6508.Description: Team project to address an unmet medical need and develop an innovative solution including the engineering design document package and proof-of-concept prototyhpe.

BMED 6517.Name: Machine Learning Biosci
BMED 6517.Description: Introduces machine learning concepts and methods, including supervised and unsupervised learning, dimension reduction and visualization. Topics are accompanied by bioinformatics and systems biology applications.

BMED 6720.Name: Biotransport
BMED 6720.Description: This graduate level course covers the analysis of fluid flow phenomena in the human body, cardiovasculature, respiratory system and other organ systems.

BMED 6743.Name: Biosolid Mechanics
BMED 6743.Description: Structure-function relationships and constitutive models for a variety of biological tissues, with an emphasis on understanding the mechanical behaviors of normal and pathological tissues. Credit not given for both BMED/ME 6783 and BMED/ME 6743. Crosslisted with ME 6743.

BMED 6775.Name: Trans Microsystems
BMED 6775.Description: Learn how to design biomedical microsystems ready for clinical and biomedical translation. Course blends theory with examples of successful biomedical research, clinical translation, and case studies.

BMED 6777.Name: Advanced Biomaterials
BMED 6777.Description: Advanced topics of biomaterials performance and engineering, including biointerfaces, host reactions to materials, and bio-inspired/smart-materials strategies. Crosslisted with CHE, ME, and MSE 6777.

BMED 6780.Name: Medical Image Processing
BMED 6780.Description: A study of methods for enhancing, analyzing, interpreting, and visualizing information from two- and three-dimensional data obtained from a variety of medical imaging modalities. Crosslisted with ECE and CS 6780.

BMED 6787.Name: Quantitative Electrophys
BMED 6787.Description: A quantitative presentation of electrophysiological systems in biological organisms, emphasizing the electrical properties and modeling of neural and cardiac cells and systems.  Crosslisted with PHYS and ECE 6787.

BMED 6793.Name: Systems Pathophysiology
BMED 6793.Description: Overview of human pathophysiology from a quantitative perspective.  A brief introduction to the application of quantitative models to the understanding of biological systems.  Crosslisted with CHE, ECE, and ME 6793.

BMED 7001.Name: Biomed Engineer Seminar
BMED 7001.Description: Graduate students of the Biomedical Engineering department (all programs) participate in seminars involving current research projects presented by faculty and invited speakers.

BMED 7005.Name: Teaching & Research II
BMED 7005.Description: This course provides the practical framework for understanding challenges faced during teaching, research, and academic life.

BMED 7011.Name: Integ Core-Int Exp&Model
BMED 7011.Description: An introduction to how engineers approach problems - via conceptual models that are then used to create wet lab models and in silico models.

BMED 7012.Name: Integ Core-Experi Design
BMED 7012.Description: This integrative core course focuses on the design of experiments to answer scientific questions, with an emphasis on the spatial and temporal scales of measurements.

BMED 7301.Name: Adv Sem-Cellular&Biomole
BMED 7301.Description: This seminar course illustrates the development of micro- and nano-scale engineering approaches for studies of biomolecules and cells and their applications to medicine.

BMED 7601.Name: Adv Sem-Neuroengineering
BMED 7601.Description: Current issues in neuroengineering.  Focus is placed on neuropathological complexity across cellular and organ level scales through literature reading, discussion, and independent study.

BMED 7742.Name: Robo Pro Prep 2
BMED 7742.Description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Selecting and applying for Internship. Developing capstone project proposal. Public speaking practice and preparation.

BMED 7785.Name: Intro Robotics Research
BMED 7785.Description: Familiarizes students with the core of robotics: mechanics, control, perception, AI, and autonomy.  Provides an introduction to the mathematical tools required in robotics research. Cross-listed with AE 7785, ECE 7785, and CS 7785.

BMED 8741.Name: Robo Capstone Project
BMED 8741.Description: Teams or individuals apply the knowledge and skills acquired throughout the MS program to a faculty supervised robotics project.

BMED 8813.Name: 3D Printing
BMED 8813.Description: Topics of current interest in biomedical engineering.

BMED 8901.Name: Special Problems
BMED 8901.Description: Individual studies and/or experimental investigations of problems of current interest in bioengineering.

BMED 8997.Name: Teaching Assistantship
BMED 8997.Description: For graduate students holding a teaching assistantship.

BMED 8998.Name: Research Assistantship
BMED 8998.Description: For graduate students holding a research assistantship.

BCP 6300.Name: Indus Hyg & Health Prin
BCP 6300.Description: This course provides an overview of the industrial hygiene discipline, which is the science of anticipation, recognition, evaluation, communication and control of occupational health stressors.

BCP 6400.Name: Hazard Materials Mgmt
BCP 6400.Description: This course introduces core elements of an effective hazardous materials management system through the study and application of regulatory standards, and consensus and proprietary standards.

BCP 6700.Name: Issues Occup Sfty & Hlth
BCP 6700.Description: This course covers the environmental issues related to the performance of buildings and the current issues in workplace safety and health.

BCP 6900.Name: Econ Risk Fin Ins Safety
BCP 6900.Description: Principles and methodology of economic analysis concepts and risk management techniques applied to occupational health & safety.

BC 2620.Name: Construction Tech II
BC 2620.Description: A continuation of Construction Technology I with an emphasis on large- scale and high-rise building, i.e., commercial building construction.

BC 2631.Name: Intro to Construction Mgt
BC 2631.Description: Provides an introduction to the construction industry with emphasis on exploring career opportunities in construction.

BC 2632.Name: Constr Materls & Methods
BC 2632.Description: The course will cover the planning and physical development process for the construction of residential, commercial and heavy/industrial projects.

BC 2634.Name: Constr Plans & Estimates
BC 2634.Description: Course focuses on reading and accessing project drawing information, and estimating quantities for pricing of materials, labor, subcontracts and equipment.

BC 3610.Name: Construction Law
BC 3610.Description: Legal aspects of construction contracts, bonds, insurance, and bidding. Owner, architect, contractor, and subcontractor relationships.

BC 3620.Name: Real Est&Cnst Fin&Acct
BC 3620.Description: General introduction to the financing of construction and real estate development projects. Emphasis on financing requirements, activities, sources, and uses.

BC 4050.Name: Building Info Modeling
BC 4050.Description: This course introduces students to BIM and the changes it has been causing to the traditional design, planning, management, construction, facility management, and contracting practices.

BC 4270.Name: Sust Commty Dsgn & Const
BC 4270.Description: An overview of the principles of smart growth, livable communities, and new urbanism and how these principles are implemented in the process from design to construction and marketing.

BC 4600.Name: Project Management II
BC 4600.Description: This course covers practical project management, technology, and tools for this approach and the  required management skills for successful execution of projects.

BC 4630.Name: Senior Capstone Project
BC 4630.Description: A senior construction project that  includes redevelopment analysis and feasibility study, project development, and construction.

BC 4660.Name: Entrepreneurship-Constru
BC 4660.Description: Basics of construction business risk assessment, looking for construction opportunities, capital investment, computerized construction business, and business failures.

BC 4672.Name: MEP Systems
BC 4672.Description: This course covers the fundamentals of mechanical, electrical, and plumbing contracting, including terminology, components, and basic design features of HVAC systems; plumbing systems; and electrical circuits and service equipment. It also encompasses the presentation of current mechanical, electrical, and plumbing drawings, specifications, and building codes.

BC 6050.Name: Building Info Modeling
BC 6050.Description: This course introduces students to BIM and the changes it has been causing to the traditional design, planning, management, construction, facility management, and contracting practices. Credit will not be awarded for both BC 4050 and BC 6050.

BC 6200.Name: Maint Mgt-Built Assets
BC 6200.Description: This course covers the processes by which a facility and its systems are serviced and maintained during the facility's life cycle.  Includes acquisition, installation, operation, maintenance, and disposal of built assets.

BC 6250.Name: Value Mgt-Integrated Dgn
BC 6250.Description: Principles and methodology of value management analysis concepts and an examination of future values and worth criteria affecting building design, construction, furnishings, and operations performance.

BC 6270.Name: Community Design&Dvlpmnt
BC 6270.Description: An overview of the principles of smart growth, livable communities and new urbanism and how these principles are implemented in the process from design to construction and marketing.

BC 6475.Name: Real Estate Develop Law
BC 6475.Description: Comprehensive overview of legal, property, and entitlement issues associated with the real estate development process.

BC 6575.Name: Real Estate Prod Finance
BC 6575.Description: Business model and financing process required to produce new real estate developments through an investigation of land acquisition, development and construction financial management.

BC 6600.Name: Fac Mgt Financial Analy
BC 6600.Description: This course covers real property concepts, issues, and topics pertinent to the facility management professional.  The topics include site selection, property market analysis, legal documents, and land use control.

BC 6650.Name: Advanced Project Mgt
BC 6650.Description: A four-phased coverage of project management including organization, planning and scheduling, control, budgeting, and ending with project testing, evaluation, and termination.

BC 6875.Name: Real Estate Dev Capstone
BC 6875.Description: Formulation and exploration of a real estate development project. Topics include business plan, market analysis, site selection, regulations, finance, project delivery, design and engineering.

BC 7200.Name: Adv Readings In BC
BC 7200.Description: This course is designed around advanced readings in research and practice for PhD students working in the building construction area.

BC 8000.Name: PhD Seminar
BC 8000.Description: This is an introduction to PhD-level research in Building Construction.

BC 8100.Name: Research Methodology
BC 8100.Description: Research design course that teaches the basics of creating credible scientific research plans with examples from construction related research.

BC 8997.Name: Teaching Assistantship
BC 8997.Description: For graduate students holding graduate teaching assistantship.

BC 8998.Name: Research Assistantship
BC 8998.Description: For graduate students holding graduate research assistantship.

BC 8999.Name: Doctorial Thesis Prep
BC 8999.Description: This course is designed to synthesize the knowledge and skills developed in previous research courses and apply them to the doctoral dissertation process for students in Building Construction.

CETL 2000.Name: Undergraduate  TA  Prep
CETL 2000.Description: This course is an introduction to the procedural information and practical skills needed to be an effective undergraduate teaching assistant.  May be used as free elective credit with department approval.

CETL 2001.Name: Fund of Peer Tutoring
CETL 2001.Description: This course is an introduction to the practical skills needed to be an effective peer tutor at Georgia Tech. May not be used towards degree requirements.

CETL 8000.Name: GTA Preparation
CETL 8000.Description: This course is an introduction to the procedural information and practical skills needed to be an effective graduate teaching assistant.

CETL 8713.Name: Teach&Learn-Higher Edu
CETL 8713.Description: This course explores how to apply evidence-based teaching practices in higher education including principles of learning, student development, inclusive teaching, and instructional strategies..

CETL 8717.Name: Course Design-Higher Ed
CETL 8717.Description: This course examines evidence-based teaching, formative and summative assessment, and educational technology as students apply the backward design process in developing a college course.

CETL 8718.Name: Teaching Capstone
CETL 8718.Description: Students apply evidence-based teaching and backward design principles, student assessment, peer and mentor feedback through supervised college teaching in this Tech to Teaching certificate capstone.

CETL 8723.Name: Acad Writ Intnl Grads
CETL 8723.Description: This course helps international graduate students enhance their academic writing skills in English through analysis and production of academic writing samples. Credit not awarded for both CETL 8723 and CETL 8722.

CETL 8796.Name: Pres Skills Intl Grads
CETL 8796.Description: This advanced oral skills class is designed to help graduate students improve their presentation skills in English for more effective communication in academic/professinal situations. Credit will not be awarded for both CETL 8795 and CETL 8796.

CHBE 2100.Name: Chem Process Principles
CHBE 2100.Description: Material and energy balances for single-phase and multi-phase processes common to chemical engineering. Phase equilibrium and analysis of reacting systems.

CHBE 2140.Name: Chem Eng Thermodynamics
CHBE 2140.Description: Principles of thermodynamics, including: first and second laws; equations of state; PVT properties; power cycles and refrigeration; phase equilibria; fugacity and activity coefficients; multi-reaction equilibrium.

CHBE 2698.Name: Research Assistantship
CHBE 2698.Description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

CHBE 2699.Name: Undergraduate Research
CHBE 2699.Description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

CHBE 2801.Name: Special Topics
CHBE 2801.Description: Topics relevant to chemical engineering not currently covered in the undergraduate curriculum are presented as demand or interest warrants.

CHBE 2801R.Name: CHBE 2801 Recitation
CHBE 2801R.Description: Designed to provide time for application of conceptual knowledge and extension of instruction. Optional and non-billable.

CHBE 3205.Name: Fluid Mechanics
CHBE 3205.Description: The basic principles of fluid mechanics are introduced and the analysis and design of equipment using these principles is practiced.

CHBE 3215.Name: Heat & Mass Transfer
CHBE 3215.Description: Fundamental principles and applications of heat and mass transfer. The analysis of chemical engineering processes and operations involving heat and mass transfer.

CHBE 3225.Name: Separations Processes
CHBE 3225.Description: Fundamentals of equilibrium-stage and continuous contacting operations.  Applications of principles to distillation, absorption/stripping, extraction, absorption, and other separation technologies.

CHBE 3300.Name: Chem Kinetics & Catal
CHBE 3300.Description: The basic principles of chemical reaction kinetics, including rate laws, mechanisms, and heterogeneous catalysis are introduced.

CHBE 4050.Name: Microelec Fabrication
CHBE 4050.Description: An elective class for students interested in fabrication of semiconductor devices focusing on the fundamentals of materials synthesis, chemical and mechanical properties, and chemical reactions. Credit will not be awarded for both CHBE 4050 and CHBE 6050.

CHBE 4200.Name: Unit Operations Laboratory
CHBE 4200.Description: This course illustrates engineering/scientific principles and physical models important to the data collection/ interpretation of processes important to the practice of chemical engineering.

CHBE 4210.Name: Bioprocess Unit Ops
CHBE 4210.Description: This course illustrates engineering/scientific principles and physical models important to the data collection/interpretation of processes important in biotechnology.

CHBE 4320.Name: Reactor Design
CHBE 4320.Description:
The basic principles of reactor design are introduced, including material and energy balances for homogeneous and heterogeneous
systems.

CHBE 4411.Name: Process Control
CHBE 4411.Description: Dynamics of chemical processes and their control. Techniques of conventional process control as well as digital control.

CHBE 4412.Name: Process Control Lab
CHBE 4412.Description: Dynamics of chemical processes and their control. Techniques of conventional process control as well as digital control. Laboratory experiments would illustrate these concepts.

CHBE 4510.Name: Proc& Prod Design& Econ
CHBE 4510.Description: Basic principles of chemical process and product design including heuristic design approaches, heat exchanger network design, optimization, and economic evaluation.  Credit not allowed for both CHBE 4510 and CHBE 4505 (or CHBE 4525).

CHBE 4515.Name: Chemical Process Safety
CHBE 4515.Description: Fundamental sources of chemical hazards and degree of risk.  Process design and hazard avoidance are used to reduce risk.

CHBE 4520.Name: Capstone CHBE Design
CHBE 4520.Description: Basic principles of chemical process and product design including heuristic design approaches heat exchanger network design, optimization, and economic evaluation.  Credit not allowed for both CHBE 4520 and CHBE 4505 (or CHBE 4525).

CHBE 4530.Name: Capstone ChBE Bio-Design
CHBE 4530.Description: Basic principles of chemical process and product design including heuristic design approaches, heat exchanger network design, optimization, and economic evaluation.  Credit not allowed for both CHBE 4530 and CHBE 4505 (or 4525).

CHBE 4698.Name: Research Assistantship
CHBE 4698.Description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

CHBE 4699.Name: Undergraduate Research
CHBE 4699.Description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

CHBE 4730.Name: Emg Tech Forest Bioprods
CHBE 4730.Description: The course provides comprehensive knowledge of the manufacture of nontraditional products from forest biomaterials. It analyzes and assesses emerging manufacturing technologies, materials and products.

CHBE 4743.Name: Sustainable Chem
CHBE 4743.Description: Life Cycle Inventory methodology will be explored as a means to develop new, sustainable products, materials and manufacturing processes

CHBE 4746.Name: Data Driven Proc Sys Eng
CHBE 4746.Description: This course covers theory of optimization and data-driven modeling methods, and examples of data-driven decision-making in the chemical process industry.

CHBE 4759.Name: Electrochem Storage
CHBE 4759.Description: An elective class for senior-level students interested in electrochemical storage and covnersion, including the fundamentals of electrochemistry and practical battery and fuel cells.

CHBE 4765.Name: Drug Design,Devlpmnt&Delivery
CHBE 4765.Description: Introduction to the pharmaceutical development process, including design of new drugs, synthesis and manufacturing issues, and methods for delivery into the body. Includes student presentations. Crosslisted with CHEM and BMED 4765.

CHBE 4767.Name: Pulp And Paper Lab
CHBE 4767.Description: Fundamentals of pulp and paper testing procedures.

CHBE 4775.Name: Polymer Science & Engr I
CHBE 4775.Description: An introduction to the chemistry, structure, and formation of polymers, physical states and transitions, physical and mechanical properties to polymer fluids and solids. Crosslisted with CHEM, ME, MSE, and PTFE 4775.

CHBE 4782.Name: Biosystems Analysis
CHBE 4782.Description: Analytical methods for modeling biological systems, including white-noise protocols for characterizing nonlinear systems. Crosslisted with BMED, ECE and ME 4782.

CHBE 4793.Name: Composite Mater& Process
CHBE 4793.Description: Basic principles of selection and design of composite materials and their manufacturing and testing. Cost factors. Laboratory exercises on manufacturing and tests. Crosslisted with AE, CEE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 4793.

CHBE 6050.Name: Microelec Fabrication
CHBE 6050.Description: An elective class for students interested in fabrication of semiconductor devices focusing on the fundamentals of materials synthesis, chemical and mechanical properties, and chemical reactions. Credit will not be awarded for both CHBE 6050 and CHBE 4050.

CHBE 6130.Name: Electrochemical Engr
CHBE 6130.Description: Electrochemical thermodynamics and kinetics. Corrosion. Applications to semiconductor devices, fuel cells, and batteries.

CHBE 6200.Name: Transport Phenomena
CHBE 6200.Description: Transfer Viscous fluid mechanics and convective heat transfer. Scaling analysis and lubrication. Stokes, and boundary layer flows.  Transport about solid bodies. Linear stability theory.

CHBE 6460.Name: MEMS Devices
CHBE 6460.Description: Introduces fundamental concepts and tools needed for the design, simulation and analysis of MEMS devices.  These include electrical, mechanical, radiant, thermal, magnetic and chemical domains.  Credit not allowed for both CHBE 6460 and ME 6460 or ECE 6460.

CHBE 6743.Name: Sustainable Chem
CHBE 6743.Description: Life Cycle Inventory methodology will be explored as a means to develop new, sustainable products, materials and manufacturing processes

CHBE 6746.Name: Data Driven Proc Sys Eng
CHBE 6746.Description: This course covers theory of optimization and data-driven modeling methods, and examples of data-driven decision-making in the chemical process industry.

CHBE 6750.Name: Prep&Reactions-Polymers
CHBE 6750.Description: A detailed treatment of the reactions involved in the synthesis of both human-made and natural polymers, including preparation and degradative reactions of polymer systems. Crosslisted with CHEM and PTFE 6750

CHBE 6765.Name: Drug Design,Devlpmnt&Delivery
CHBE 6765.Description: Introduction to the pharmaceutical development process, including design of new drugs, synthesis and manufacturing issues, and methods of delivery into the body. Includes student presentations.  Crosslisted with BMED 6765 and CHBE 6765.

CHBE 6768.Name: Polymer Structure& Props
CHBE 6768.Description: Formulations and analysis of molecular and phenomenological models of elastic and viscoelastic behavior, development and description of structure, and fundamental aspects of structure-property relations.  Crosslisted with ME, PTFE, and MSE 6768.

CHBE 6777.Name: Advanced Biomaterials
CHBE 6777.Description: Advanced topics of biomaterials performance and engineering, including biointerfaces, host reactions of materials, and bio-inspired/smart-materials strategies. Crosslisted with BMED, ME, and MSE 6777.

CHBE 7774.Name: Fatigue-Materials&Struct
CHBE 7774.Description: Mechanical and microstructural aspects of nucleation and growth of cracks under cyclic loading conditions, notch effects, cumulative damage, multiaxial loading, and fatigue crack propagation.  Crosslisted with AE, CEE, ME, and MSE 7774.

CHBE 8002.Name: Seminar - Chemical Engr
CHBE 8002.Description: Seminars involving current research projects presented by graduate students, faculty, and invited speakers.

CHBE 8902.Name: Special Problems
CHBE 8902.Description: Special Problems for Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering

CHEM 1211K.Name: Principles of Chemistry I
CHEM 1211K.Description: First course in a two-semester sequence covering the fundamental principles and applications of chemistry designed for science majors. Topics to be covered include composition of matter, stoichiometry, periodic relations, and nomenclature. Laboratory exercises supplement the lecture material. Credit not allowed for both CHEM 1310 and CHEM 1211K.

CHEM 1212K.Name: Principles of Chemistry II
CHEM 1212K.Description: Second course in a two-semester sequence covering the fundamental principles and applications of chemistry designed for science majors. Laboratory exercises supplement the lecture material.

CHEM 1310.Name: Prin of Gen Chem for Engr
CHEM 1310.Description: A first course in chemistry, surveying its fundamental laws and theories, for some engineering majors. It can serve as the first course in a two course sequence where CHEM 1315 is the second course. Topics include atomic structure; bonding theory; stoichiometry; properties of solids, liquids and gases; chemical thermodynamics; electrochemistry; and kinetics. Credit not allowed for both CHEM 1310 and CHEM 1211K.

CHEM 1315.Name: Survey of Org Chm for Engr
CHEM 1315.Description: Second or third course in chemistry for some engineering majors. The principles of organic chemistry will be surveyed as a basis for understanding materials, biochemical processes and applications. Credit not awarded for both CHEM 1315 and CHEM 2311.

CHEM 2216L.Name: Quant Chem Lab
CHEM 2216L.Description: Laboratory practice of quantitative chemical analysis

CHEM 2216R.Name: CHEM 2216 Recitation
CHEM 2216R.Description: Recitation to support the theory of quantitative chemical analysis.

CHEM 2311.Name: Organic Chemistry I
CHEM 2311.Description: An introduction to structure and reactivity of organic molecules. Credit not awarded for both CHEM 2311 and CHEM 1315.

CHEM 2312.Name: Organic Chemistry II
CHEM 2312.Description: The second course in the series dealing with the structure and reactivity of organic molecules. Credit not awarded for both CHEM 2312 and CHEM 2313.

CHEM 2380.Name: Synthesis Lab I
CHEM 2380.Description: Methods for preparation, isolation, and characterization of complex organic molecules, natural products, and polymers.

CHEM 2601.Name: Professional Skills
CHEM 2601.Description: An introduction to technical and communication skills utilized in upper level chemistry and biochemistry courses with additional focus on resume building and professional development.

CHEM 2694.Name: Intern Assistantship
CHEM 2694.Description: Undergraduate Internship for which the student is paid, Freshmen and Sophomores only.

CHEM 2695.Name: Undergraduate Internship
CHEM 2695.Description: Undergraduate Internship for academic credit, Freshmen and Sophomores only.

CHEM 2698.Name: Research Assistantship
CHEM 2698.Description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

CHEM 2699.Name: Undergraduate Research
CHEM 2699.Description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

CHEM 2801.Name: Special Topics
CHEM 2801.Description: Lecture course in current special topics in chemistry and biochemistry. Topics will vary from year to year.

CHEM 3111.Name: Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 3111.Description: A study of the reactions and structures of inorganic compounds and principles, generalizations and theories that assist in understanding their behavior.

CHEM 3216.Name: Analytical Chem Lecture
CHEM 3216.Description: Introduction to the theory of modern chemical analysis.

CHEM 3216L.Name: Analytical Chem Lab
CHEM 3216L.Description: Introduction to the practice of modern chemical analysis.

CHEM 3371.Name: Organic Chem Lab
CHEM 3371.Description: Multi-step organic synthesis and inorganic synthesis. Use of chemical literature and advanced spectroscopic techniques.

CHEM 3380.Name: Synthesis Lab II
CHEM 3380.Description: Multi-step organic and inorganic synthesis.  Use of the chemical literature and advanced spectroscopic techniques.

CHEM 3411.Name: Physical Chemistry I
CHEM 3411.Description: Chemical thermodynamics, energetics of chemical reactions, changes of state, and electrochemistry.

CHEM 3412.Name: Physical Chemistry II
CHEM 3412.Description: Quantum mechanics, atomic and molecular structure, bonding theory, molecular spectroscopy, statistical mechanics.

CHEM 3481.Name: Physical Chem Lab I
CHEM 3481.Description: Laboratory investigations of physical principles applied to chemical systems.

CHEM 3511.Name: Survey of Biochemistry
CHEM 3511.Description: Introductory course in biochemistry dealing with the chemistry and biochemistry of proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, nucleic acids, and other biomolecules. Credit not awarded for both CHEM 3511 and (CHEM 4511 or CHEM 3521).

CHEM 3521.Name: Biochemistry I
CHEM 3521.Description: The chemistry and biochemistry of proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, nucleic acids, and other biomolecules. Credit not awarded for both CHEM 3521 and (CHEM 4511 or CHEM 3511).

CHEM 3522.Name: Biochemistry II
CHEM 3522.Description: The chemistry and biochemistry of proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, nucleic acids, and other biomolecules.

CHEM 3700.Name: Alternative Energy
CHEM 3700.Description: Scientific principles governing the current and future approaches in solar photo-voltaics, fuel cells, biomass conversion, nuclear energy and wind power.

CHEM 4113.Name: Inorg Energy Conversion
