ID 1012.Description: Art and design theory and practice in Industrial Design including an introduction to process, methodology, ergonomics, research tools and user research. Focus is on CAD and digital prototyping.

ID 1102.Name: Intro Industrial Des 2
ID 1102.Description: Introduction to Industrial Design – a survey of evolving diverse career options and the designer’s impact on society. Emphasis is on user experience and interaction design.

ID 1402.Name: Intro Graphic Comm 2
ID 1402.Description: Introduction to graphic design history and practice, composition, layout, color, typography, photography, social media & videography. This second course in the sequence will emphasize digital skill development.

ID 1419.Name: Intro Sketch & Model 2
ID 1419.Description: Introduction to intermediate visual representation techniques that empower designers of products, services and systems through sketching, model making, computer-assisted drawing, rapid prototyping, and other methods.

ID 2024.Name: Ind Des Studio 2
ID 2024.Description: This course applies structured user-centered design methods to research and exploration of product design and function, and introduces concepts of universal design.

ID 2102.Name: 3D Modeling
ID 2102.Description: This course introduces 3D modeling methods for solid and surface modeling in CAD software. Students create multi-component assembly drawings and explore rendering techniques for product design.

ID 2202.Name: Hist-Modern Indust Dsgn
ID 2202.Description: History and development of industrial design from the beginning of the Industrial Revolution to the present.

ID 2242.Name: History of Art 2
ID 2242.Description: This course surveys the major artistic movements and aesthetics of the 17th, 18th, 19th, 20th, and early 21st centuries in painting, sculpture and architecture.

ID 2320.Name: Human Factors in Design
ID 2320.Description: This course examines the theory of Human Factors to provide a working knowledge of the physical and cognitive attributes of people that designers must accomodate.

ID 2325.Name: User Cent Design Methods
ID 2325.Description: This course introduces students to user-centric design methods used to identify, understand, assess and prioritize the neuroscience factors and perceptions that contribute to more effective product design and human-centered design solutions.

ID 2401.Name: Visual Design Thinking
ID 2401.Description: Introduction to techniques to help designers build a vocabulary to support effective visual communication including fundamentals of layout, sketching, rendering, schematics, information graphics & storyboarding.

ID 2510.Name: Intro Smart Product Des
ID 2510.Description: This course provides an introduction to smart product design including the basics of sensor technologies, electronics and programming required to produce working product concept prototypes.

ID 3042.Name: Product Dev Studio 2
ID 3042.Description: The application of systematic user-centered design methods to projects focused on the design development of 'real-world' products, services, interfaces & systems in collaboration with external sponsors.

ID 3052.Name: Interactive ID Studio 2
ID 3052.Description: The application of systematic user-centered design methods to projects focused on new applications of sensor-based technologies with an emphasis on interactive environments, interfaces, navigation and mobility.

ID 3201.Name: Design for Social Good
ID 3201.Description: Students explore socially and environmentally responsible industrial design practices at home and abroad, and partner with local organizations to develop community-based design projects.

ID 3301.Name: Materials I
ID 3301.Description: This course examines the characteristics, production technologies, histories, and environmental impacts of nine categories of renewable materials familiar to product and product system design.

ID 3320.Name: Design Methods
ID 3320.Description: This course introduces students to current user-centric design methods used to identify, understand, assess and prioritize the factors and perceptions that contribute to more effective product design and human-centered design solutions.

ID 3803.Name: Experiential Prototyping
ID 3803.Description: Topics of current interest in industrial design.

ID 3813.Name: Soft Goods Design
ID 3813.Description: Topics of current interest in Industrial Design.

ID 4062.Name: ID Capstone Des Studio 2
ID 4062.Description: Comprehensive team-based projects incorporating an iterative approach to design development of products, & systems with emphasis on integration of research, user-centered design, prototyping, usability and testing.

ID 4072.Name: Invention Studio 2
ID 4072.Description: Comprehensive projects incorporating an iterative approach to user-centered design development of products, systems & services with emphasis on invention, innovation and entrepreneurship.

ID 4082.Name: ID/ME Colab Des Studio 2
ID 4082.Description: An interdisciplinary team-based approach to integrate industrial design and engineering competencies in user-centered design development of products and systems with emphasis on humanitarian projects.

ID 4202.Name: Professional Practice
ID 4202.Description: Principles of consulting and corporate industrial design including preparation of the professional portfolio.

ID 4206.Name: Culture of Objects
ID 4206.Description: This seminar surveys the theories and methodologies within the field of industrial design that locate meaning in the designed object as derived from culture.

ID 4450.Name: Portfolio Development
ID 4450.Description: The portfolio development course provides students with a structured approach to preparing a professional visual record of their work in print and digital formats.

ID 4813.Name: ST: Design for Climate Action
ID 4813.Description: Special topics in sustainability not included in the professional curriculum.

ID 4833.Name: Spec Top: Collaborative
ID 4833.Description: Application of the design process to advanced multidisciplinary problems by a team. Projects from a range of interest areas:  consumer, industrial products, transportation, furniture.

ID 4843.Name: Brand Startup
ID 4843.Description: Special topics in history and theory not included in the professional curriculum.

ID 6101.Name: Human Centered Design
ID 6101.Description: This course examines design artifacts in relation to the human body, aging, disabilities, and environments with a perspective of  human-centered methodology that includes data gathering, analysis, and usability.

ID 6103.Name: Graduate Studio B
ID 6103.Description: This course is a project-based ID studio that gives students an overview of and practice with the insights-driven, iterative ID process.

ID 6106.Name: 3D Design Methods
ID 6106.Description: This course teaches students about the 3D digital  tools needed to develop products for human form.  By learning how to model, render and animate, students can better express their research, ideations and designs.

ID 6107.Name: Integrated Product Des
ID 6107.Description: Introduction to smart products teaches students to create IOT products. Students work with sensors and signals, U/I design, and multi-platform prototyping.

ID 6108.Name: Survey of ID History
ID 6108.Description: This course surveys the history of industrial design from the Industrial Revolution to contemporary times.

ID 6212.Name: Studio 2 Health&Wellness
ID 6212.Description: This course explores the application of systematic product design methods to projects that focus on the design of new and/or improved health products, interactions, and delivery of services.

ID 6213.Name: Studio 2 Interact Product
ID 6213.Description: This course explores the application of systematic product design methods to projects that focus on the design development of new/or improved interactive or smart products.

ID 6400.Name: Master's Project
ID 6400.Description: Under the guidance of a faculty member, students explore a design project that relates to advance theoritical  research through a human prespective with a design and/or technology  focus on a product.  The project may include areas  in instructional design, human-computer interaction, learning, neuroscience, perception, product design, user-centered design, and usability.

ID 6403.Name: Intro to Thesis Studies
ID 6403.Description: This introduction to thesis course helps students understand the human-centered research methods, analytical tools, and design processes used in developing a thesis or project in graduate studies.

ID 6420.Name: Advanced Sketching
ID 6420.Description: This class will focus on developing advanced, traditional (non-digital) sketching, rendering, and presentation techniques.

ID 6515.Name: Interface Prototyping
ID 6515.Description: This course focuses on interface prototypes, how these are used throughout the design process and the varity of ways they can be created with different technologies.  Through interface prototypes, students learn how to express their research, receive user feedback, explore user perceptions, and improve their designs.

ID 6520.Name: Crafting Design Methods
ID 6520.Description: Traditional craftwork and how we can use material change, scale shifts, methods of manufacture, and algorithmic analysis to incorporate and revitalize these traditions into design.

ID 6620.Name: Soft Goods Design
ID 6620.Description: This graduate course focuses on product opportunities highlighting user benefits from soft material integration.

ID 6763.Name: Design Interactv Environ
ID 6763.Description: Investigate and design ambient, intelligent, interactive interfaces and computational applications in tangible and physical environment to support health, wellness and quality of life.  Credit not allowed for both ID 6763 and COA 6763 or CS 6763.

ID 6998.Name: HCI Master's Project
ID 6998.Description: Final project for students completing a Human-Computer Interaction master's degree in the Digitial Media track. Repeatable for multi-semester projects.

ID 7000.Name: Master's Thesis
ID 7000.Description: Under the guidance of a faculty member, students explore advance  theoretical  research through a human perspective in areas instructional design, human-computer interaction, learning, neuroscience, perception, product design, user-centered design, and/or usability.

ID 8903.Name: Special Problems in HCI
ID 8903.Description: Small-group of individual investigation of advanced topics in human-computer interaction. Guided study and research.

ID 8997.Name: Teaching Assistantship
ID 8997.Description: For graduate students holding graduate teaching assistantships.

ID 8998.Name: Research Assistantship
ID 8998.Description: For graduate students holding graduate research assistantships.

INTA 1050.Name: The World Today
INTA 1050.Description: Introduction to current issues of politics, geography, and history around the globe, using a wide variety of media and sources.

INTA 1110.Name: Intro to Int'l Relations
INTA 1110.Description: An introduction to the major principles, concepts, actors, and theories of the international system and their application to current issues in world affairs.

INTA 1200.Name: American Government
INTA 1200.Description: Examines American government in relation to other political and economic systems in countries around the world. Includes study of the Constitution of Georgia. Credit not allowed for both POL 1101 and INTA 1200.

INTA 2001.Name: Careers In Intl Affairs
INTA 2001.Description: Reinforces career development and planning process for international affairs majors.  Includes facilitation of decision-making skills, job search strategies, self-assessment, and overview from industry speakers.  Credit not allowed for both INTA 2001 and INTA 1001.

INTA 2010.Name: Empirical Methods
INTA 2010.Description: Develops skills in research design, model building, and hypothesis construction. Provides experience in using computer software programs to perform statistical tests including t-tests, chi-square, and regression.

INTA 2030.Name: Ethics in Int'l Affairs
INTA 2030.Description: Surveys the main traditions and theories of international ethics with a focus on intervention and the use of force, human rights, self-determination, and global distributive justice.

INTA 2040.Name: Sci,Tech & Int'l Affairs
INTA 2040.Description: An overview of science and technology as a determinant in the development and functioning of states and societies worldwide and the international context for the development of science and technology.

INTA 2050.Name: Intro to Global Develpmt
INTA 2050.Description: Mainstream and critical approaches to development, the role of diverse institutions and projects, and implications for sustainability in the countries of the global south.

INTA 2120.Name: Intro to Intl Security
INTA 2120.Description: Introduction to the role of theory and provide an understanding of the significance of various issues in international security.

INTA 2220.Name: Govt & Pol - Europe
INTA 2220.Description: A comparative analysis of the politics and major institutions of the countries of contemporary Western Europe.

INTA 2221.Name: Politics of the EU
INTA 2221.Description: Introduction and overview of the history and politics of the European Union from its inception to the new era of development under the 2009 Lisbon Treaty.

INTA 2230.Name: Govt & Politics of Asia
INTA 2230.Description: An introduction to the major issues and aspects of the politics, societies, and cultures of East Asia, and the changing role of the region in international affairs.

INTA 2901.Name: Special Problems
INTA 2901.Description: Independent study with a faculty member.

INTA 3031.Name: Human Rights
INTA 3031.Description: Explores how processes of globalization and advances in communication and technology have heightened and shaped human rights as a concern in international politics.

INTA 3050.Name: Global Citizenship
INTA 3050.Description: Explore the meaning of global citizenship in scholarly and public debates and how it is "practiced" by individuals and "institutionalized" by universities, corporations and organizations.

INTA 3101.Name: Int'l Institutions
INTA 3101.Description: Scrutinizes the evolution of international institutions, and juxtaposes competing theoretical approaches for understanding the changing roles and functions of institutions in world affairs.

INTA 3102.Name: Problem of Proliferation
INTA 3102.Description: Explores the political and economic issues, both international as well as domestic, involved in the spread of the weapons of mass destruction since the end of the Second World War.

INTA 3110.Name: U.S. Foreign Policy
INTA 3110.Description: Analyzes the formulation and implementation of America's foreign policy from 1914 to the present, stressing economic, political, and strategic factors.

INTA 3121.Name: Russia and Eurasia
INTA 3121.Description: Examines the many dimensions of the foreign and security policies of Russia and the other new post-Soviet states of Russia and Eurasia.

INTA 3131.Name: Pacific Security Issues
INTA 3131.Description: Examines past, present, and future security concerns in the Pacific, including the Korean peninsula, Japanese defense, the emergence of China as a military power, and the forward basing of American troops and materiel.

INTA 3203.Name: Comparative Politics
INTA 3203.Description: Contrasts competing theoretical perspectives in the comparative analysis of political systems.

INTA 3231.Name: Gov't & Politics-Japan
INTA 3231.Description: Examines the main institutions, policies, and politics of contemporary Japan. Investigates the impact of social, cultural, and economic forces on Japan's government and politics.

INTA 3242.Name: Soccer & Global Politics
INTA 3242.Description: An examination of regional and national identity, development, and politics through the history of soccer.

INTA 3260.Name: Middle East Relations
INTA 3260.Description: Course will provide an in-depth understanding of the Arab-Israeli conflict using theories of international relations and comparative politics.

INTA 3301.Name: Int'l Political Econ
INTA 3301.Description: Analyzes the relationship between political and economic issues in international affairs. Examines the interaction of states and markets in the context of trade, investment, and production.

INTA 3303.Name: Pol Economy-Development
INTA 3303.Description: Surveys theories of economic development and political change, and examines a range of cases that include the European-American experience, the East Asian episode, and the transition from socialism.

INTA 4007.Name: Intell & Int'l Security
INTA 4007.Description: This coures examines the history, nature and business of secret intelligence as a critical element of national and international security, with special emphasis given to its role in the global war on terror, and the relationship between the intelligence community and policy makers.

INTA 4060.Name: International Law
INTA 4060.Description: Explores major issues, concepts and cases in public international law and their policy ramifications. Specific topics include human rights, armed conflict, crimes against humanity, and the environment.

INTA 4101.Name: Vietnam War Politics
INTA 4101.Description: Strategic approaches and political environments of the United States, North Vietnam, China, and the USSR during 1954-1975 Vietnam War.

INTA 4332.Name: Chinese Institutions
INTA 4332.Description: Supervised field research on the Chinese institutions and policy-making process especially in the areas of economic and social issues.

INTA 4500.Name: INTA Pro-Seminar
INTA 4500.Description: Capstone experience in which students formulate strategies and policies to cope with international problems.  Themes vary from seminar to seminar.  Credit not allowed for both INTA 4500 and INTA 4400.

INTA 4742.Name: Mod, Sim&Military Gaming
INTA 4742.Description: Creation and use of modeling and simulation tools to analyze and train students regarding strategic events in international relations.  Credit not allowed for both INTA 4742 and INTA 6742 (or CSE 6742 or CS 4343).

INTA 4744.Name: Global Develop Capstone
INTA 4744.Description: Teams develop solutions to multidisciplinary problems selected from globalization, food security, infrastructure, health, water, sanitation, hygiene, ecosystem resilience, services, capacity building, and urbanization.

INTA 4901.Name: Special Problems
INTA 4901.Description: Independent study with a faculty member.

INTA 6004.Name: Model,Forecast&Decision
INTA 6004.Description: This course introduces modeling and forecasting in strategic decision making, analysis of long-term developments, path gaming, formal analysis of games, and simulation.

INTA 6015.Name: Technology& Military Org
INTA 6015.Description: Explores changes in military technology, organization, and operations leading to new conceptions of the conduct of warfare as a result of revolutions in military affairs.

INTA 6102.Name: Intl Relations Theory
INTA 6102.Description: This course provides an introduction to theoretical approaches to understanding international relations.  The focus of the course is on system-level theories and sub-systematic-level theories.

INTA 6103.Name: International Security
INTA 6103.Description: Examines traditional and nontraditional issues in international security, including the uses of military force, military strategy and policy, arms control, peacekeeping, the environment, and migration.

INTA 6105.Name: Intl Institutional Dsgn
INTA 6105.Description: This course examines international institutions and their effect on foreign policy decision makers. Specific topics include: the theoretical study of cooperation; supranatural organizations and informal institutions.

INTA 6111.Name: US Foreign Secur Strat
INTA 6111.Description: This course focuses on the design and implementation of U.S. foreign policy and national strategy in the areas of arms control, the Third World, and economic policy.

INTA 6122.Name: STS Sci Tech Nat Sec
INTA 6122.Description: Topics in the study of the relationship between national security and the scientific-technological enterprise from diverse perspectives

INTA 6131.Name: Pacific Security Issues
INTA 6131.Description: Examines past, present, and future security concerns in the Pacific, including the Korean pennisula, Japanese defense, the emergence of China as a military power, and the forward basing of American troops and material.

INTA 6202.Name: Comparative Politics
INTA 6202.Description: This course surveys the major political types of the late twentieth century world and explores their various development characteristics.

INTA 6302.Name: Intl Political Economy
INTA 6302.Description: This course is an introduction to the politics of international economic relations.  Major theoretical approaches are applied to international trade, international monetary relations, and global production in the modern era.

INTA 6306.Name: Globalization
INTA 6306.Description: Research seminar exploring theoretical perspectives on globalization and the political and economic issues facing modern states and their citizens in a "borderless" world.

INTA 6450.Name: Data Analytics and Security
INTA 6450.Description: Explores use of big data techniques to problems at the national and international levels.  Topics may include cybersecurity, surveillance, economic development, behavioral prediction and manipulation.

INTA 6720.Name: Politics Tech Prolif
INTA 6720.Description:
This seminar course is designed specifically to encourage new thinking and creative effort on nuclear deterrence and strategic 
stability for our global future.

INTA 6742.Name: Mod, Sim&Military Gaming
INTA 6742.Description: Focuses on the creation and use of modeling and simulation tools to analyze and train students regarding strategic events in international relations. Credit not allowed for both INTA 6742 and CSE 6742 (or INTA 4742 or CS 4343).

INTA 6745.Name: Info&Com Tech&Global Dev
INTA 6745.Description: Focus on technology design, adoption, and use as seen through the lens of global development.

INTA 8001.Name: Sci,Tech&Intl Affairs II
INTA 8001.Description: Research course introducing engineers and scientists to issues in science and technology as related to international security policy and development.

INTA 8997.Name: Teaching Assistantship
INTA 8997.Description: For graduate students with a teaching assistantship.

INTA 8998.Name: Research Assistantship
INTA 8998.Description: For graduate students with a research assistantship.

IL 6450.Name: Analytical Methods
IL 6450.Description: This course provides an overview of optimization, statistical, and stochastic models and methods with special emphasis on application to logistics.

IL 6451.Name: Demand and Yield Mgt
IL 6451.Description: This course focuses on demand estimation and modeling and revenue management.

IL 6452.Name: Reverse Green Logistics
IL 6452.Description: This course addresses issues, driving forces, and analytical approaches to aid in designing operating reverse logistics systems.

IL 6453.Name: Labor Relations
IL 6453.Description: This course compares labor practices in Europe, North America, and Asia with special attention on the influences on logistics.

IL 6454.Name: European Trade&Transport
IL 6454.Description: This course provides an overview of legal, cultural, political, and infrastructure issues influencing logistics in Europe.

IL 6455.Name: Finance for Logistics
IL 6455.Description: This course provides an in-depth understanding of concepts of finance that relate to logistics, such as valuing logistics activities and measuring logistics performance.

IL 6465.Name: Marketing Channels
IL 6465.Description: This course focuses on logistics and supply chain issues as they impact the global marketing strategies of companies.

IL 6472.Name: Supply Chain Lab III
IL 6472.Description: This course integrates supply chain management techniques in the Americas, Asia, and Europe through case studies.

IL 6475.Name: Cases-Intl Logistics I
IL 6475.Description: In this course, cases are used to integrate strategic, management, and operating issues in international logistics and supply chain design.

IL 6480.Name: Supply Chain Lab I
IL 6480.Description: This course integrates supply chain management techniques in the region through readings, case studies, meetings and site visits.  Typically Supply Chain Lab I focuses on the US.  Credit not allowed for both IL 6480 and IL 6470.

IL 6481.Name: Supply Chain Lab II
IL 6481.Description: This course integrates supply chain management techniques in the region through readings, case studies, meetings and site visits.  Typically Supply Chain Lab II focuses on Europe.  Credit not allowed for both IL 6481 and IL 6471.

INTN 2003.Name: Internship
INTN 2003.Description: Supervised professional work experience in the United States for undergraduate freshman or sophomore interns working 10-19 hours a week in their major field of study for a semester.

INTN 2006.Name: P/T Professional Internship
INTN 2006.Description: Supervised domestic work experience for freshmen and sophomore interns working 20-29 hours per week in their major field of study for a semester.

INTN 2009.Name: P/T Professional Internship
INTN 2009.Description: Supervised domestic work experience for freshmen and sophomore interns working 30 to 35 hours per week in their major field of study for a semester.

INTN 3011.Name: Intl Intern Exp
INTN 3011.Description: Undergradute interns working outside the United States.

INTN 3016.Name: Intl Intern Exp
INTN 3016.Description: Supervised professional international experience for undergraduate interns working abroad full-time in their major field of study for approximately 50% of a semester.

INTN 3019.Name: Intl Intern Exp
INTN 3019.Description: Supervised professional international experience for undergraduate interns working abroad full-time in their major field of study for approximately 75% of a semester.

INTN 4003.Name: Internship
INTN 4003.Description: Supervised professional work experience in the United States for undergraduate junior or senior interns working 10-19 hours a week in their major field of study for a semester.

INTN 4006.Name: P/T Professional Internship
INTN 4006.Description: Supervised domestic work experience for junior or senior interns working 20-29 hours per week in their major field of study for a semester.

INTN 4009.Name: P/T Professional Internship
INTN 4009.Description: Supervised domestic work experience for junior or senior interns working 30-35 hours per week in their major field of study for a semester.

INTN 6003.Name: Graduate Internship Prog Res
INTN 6003.Description: Supervised work experience for Master’s and Ph.D. student interns working 6 - 9 hours per week in their field of study; suitable for part-time GRAs and GTAs.

INTN 6004.Name: Grad Intern Program PT
INTN 6004.Description: Supervised work experience for Master’s and Ph.D. student interns working 10 - 15 hours per week in their field of study for a semester.

INTN 6006.Name: Grad Int Prog Hit
INTN 6006.Description: Supervised work experience for Master’s and Ph.D. student interns working 16 - 20 hours per week in their field of study for a semester.

INTN 6009.Name: Grad Int Prog Lft
INTN 6009.Description: Supervised work experience for Master’s and Ph.D. student interns working 21-31 hours per week in their field of study for a semester.

INTN 6012.Name: Grad Int Prog FT
INTN 6012.Description: Supervised work experience for Master’s and Ph.D. student interns working 32 - 40 hours per week in their field of study for a semester.

IMBA 6040.Name: Global Economics
IMBA 6040.Description: Participants are provided with a non-traditional approach using an analytical method with a global perspective to the concepts and role of economics in the world environment.

IMBA 6081.Name: Manf and Service Mgt
IMBA 6081.Description: Covers the basic conceptual and analytical skills that are required in managing operations and confronting operational problems in competitive markets.

IMBA 6090.Name: Managing Marketing
IMBA 6090.Description: Students are provided with an understanding of marketing and consumer behavior concepts and tools with an international environment approach.

IMBA 6132.Name: Strategy
IMBA 6132.Description: Integrate knowledge of the functional areas of a business to understand how firms gain and sustain a competitive advantage in a globally competitive environment.

IMBA 6301.Name: Anal of Global Environ
IMBA 6301.Description: Analysis of a specific region through an international study tour with emphasis on understanding its economy, culture and business environment.

IAC 2002.Name: Science,Eng,and Religion
IAC 2002.Description: This course gathers diverse students serious about faith to explore topics at the intersection of science, engineering, and religion.

JAPN 1001.Name: Elementary Japanese I
JAPN 1001.Description: Essential principles of Japanese grammar and phonetics, acquisition of vocabulary through conversational exercises, video, and tape material. Introduction to the kana writing system. Humanities credit is awarded for JAPN 1001 upon successful completion of JAPN 1002 or JAPN 2001.

JAPN 1002.Name: Elementary Japanese II
JAPN 1002.Description: Continuation of JAPN 1001. Introduction to kanji symbols.

JAPN 3001.Name: Advanced Japanese I
JAPN 3001.Description: Learn advanced grammar structures and develop the ability to produce longer conversations involving complex styles and levels of speech.  More kanji.

JAPN 3401.Name: Popular Culture in Japan
JAPN 3401.Description: This course introduces students to Japanese society, history, and language through popular culture. Repeatable for credit if taken with different course theme. Taught in English.

JAPN 4183.Name: JAPN Cul/Soc Thru Songs
JAPN 4183.Description: Students will be exposed to songs in different historical, societal and cultural contexts of Japan, and appreciate their aesthetic quality. Taught in Japanese.

JAPN 4193.Name: Documentary Cul/Society
JAPN 4193.Description: The course explores Japanese culture, language, society, and history through documentary films. Taught in Japanese.

JAPN 4231.Name: Design Websites in Jpn
JAPN 4231.Description: This course provides instruction in text input in Japanese and explores language and intercultural communication issues when designing Web pages in Japanese.  Taught in Japanese.

JAPN 4500.Name: Intercultural Seminar
JAPN 4500.Description: Integrates cross-cultural research and reflection into discussion of current issues in Japan.  Intended for students who have had some study-abroad experience in Japan. Conducted mostly in Japanese.

JAPN 4699.Name: Undergraduate Research
JAPN 4699.Description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

JAPN 6183.Name: Songs: Culture & Society
JAPN 6183.Description: Students will be able to appreciate anime's significance in historical, societal and cultural contexts, as well as the aesthetic quality of its form. Taught in Japanese.

JAPN 6193.Name: JAPN Cul & Soc Thr Doc
JAPN 6193.Description: The course explores Japanese culture, language, society, and history through documentary films. Taught in Japanese.

JAPN 6500.Name: Intercultural Seminar
JAPN 6500.Description: Integrates cross-cultural research and reflection into discussion of current issues in Japan. For students who have had some study/work-abroad experience in Japan. Conducted in Japanese.

JAPN 8903.Name: Special Problems
JAPN 8903.Description: Provides the special instruction required under special programs.

KOR 3002.Name: Advanced Korean II
KOR 3002.Description: Further development of richer perspectives about Korean culture and enhanced skills in reading, writing, and vocabulary.  Conducted in Korean.

KOR 3100.Name: Kor Convers & Culture
KOR 3100.Description: The course will focus on developing students’ conversation skills and grammatical knowledge required for 3000-level courses or higher. Taught in Korean.

KOR 3410.Name: Korean Culture Old & New
KOR 3410.Description: Comparison and contrast of aspects of the past and present. Topics include politics, music, the family, popular culture, war and many others. Taught in English.

KOR 4002.Name: Select Rdngs of Mod Kor
KOR 4002.Description: This course aims to enhance students' Korean skills through advanced reading and comprehension, translation, grammar, and writing practice.  Taught in Korean.

KOR 4500.Name: Intercultural Seminar
KOR 4500.Description: Enhancement of students' skills and understanding of intercultural communication, skills, and behaviors for globalized business, research, and politics related to South Korea. Taught in Korean.

KOR 4699.Name: Undergraduate Research
KOR 4699.Description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

LS 0398.Name: Mathematical Skills
LS 0398.Description: Intense review of arithmetic and algebra skills.  Development of mathematics study skills.

LING 2100.Name: Intro to Linguistics
LING 2100.Description: Introductory course that surveys various fields in linguistics, including first/second language acquisition, phonetics/phonology, morphology/syntax, semantics/pragmatics, language variation, computational linguistics/natural language processing, and writing systems.  Credit not allowed for both LING 2100 and LING 2001.

LING 3100.Name: Apps of Linguistics
LING 3100.Description: Explores the relation of language (and linguistic theories) to real-world domains including language acquisition, education, gender, advertising, politics, law, and medicine.  Taught in English.

LMC 2100.Name: Intro to STAC
LMC 2100.Description: Relation to other courses, programs and curricula: As the introductory course to the LMC Science, Technology and Culture thread, this course explores the way in which disciplines construct and represent the knowledge they generate.

LMC 2200.Name: Intro to Gender Studies
LMC 2200.Description: This course introduces the cultural concept of gender, examining topics such as biology and gender, social constructions of gender, and the psychology of sexual roles.

LMC 2400.Name: Intro to Media Studies
LMC 2400.Description: This course offers an introduction to the historical development and cultural impact of various forms of media print, radio, television, film, and interactive electronic applications.

LMC 2410.Name: Intro to Game Studies
LMC 2410.Description: Introduction to the games studies and game designs.

LMC 2500.Name: Intro to Film
LMC 2500.Description: Introduces film techniques and vocabulary in an historical and cultural context. Written texts are supplemented by viewings of specific shots, scenes, and films.

LMC 2661.Name: Theatre Production I
LMC 2661.Description: In this hands-on course, students learn theatrical construction and painting techniques while building scenery for DramaTech productions.

LMC 2662.Name: Theatre Production II
LMC 2662.Description: In this hands-on course, students create the lighting, property, and costume effects for two DramaTech Theatre productions.

LMC 2720.Name: Prin of Visual Design
LMC 2720.Description: Studio-based course that provides students with basic skills needed to create digital visual images and to analyze designs from historical and theoretical perspectives.

LMC 2730.Name: Construct-Moving Image
LMC 2730.Description: Provides the student with the conceptual, formal, aesthetic, and technical approaches to reconsider film, videos, and animation within the context of emerging digital forms.

LMC 3062.Name: Film Acting Workshop
LMC 3062.Description: A workshop-based introduction to screen acting and the acting profession for the student who is interested in participating in the film and television industries.

LMC 3112.Name: Evolution&Industrial Age
LMC 3112.Description: Connects later nineteenth century scientific and technological concepts and discoveries, particularly theories of evolution, to the literature and culture of the industrial age.

LMC 3202.Name: Global Science Fiction
LMC 3202.Description: Examines the elements of fiction and what has made fiction, especially the novel, distinctive, popular, and enduring. Readings may include formal, cultural, and historical theories.

LMC 3204.Name: Poetry and Poetics
LMC 3204.Description: A study of traditions of poetic practice and poetic theory in English through intensive line by line readings of poems from different periods in literary history.

LMC 3206.Name: Persuasive Communication
LMC 3206.Description: Examines ways in which forms and media of communication create and are created by other cultural constructs.

LMC 3209.Name: Asian Amer Lit & Culture
LMC 3209.Description: Explores Asian American literary and cultural contributions since the nineteenth century through the lens of migration histories and global events foundational to Asian American experience.

LMC 3212.Name: Women, Lit & Culture
LMC 3212.Description: Students in this course will analyze writings by women and examine feminist and other relevant cultural critiques of literature.

LMC 3215.Name: Science Fiction Film TV
LMC 3215.Description: This course investigates science fiction as the genre developed during film history and has become one of the most popular forms of television narrative.

LMC 3226.Name: Major Authors
LMC 3226.Description: An examination of the works and career of a major author in historical and cultural context.

LMC 3228.Name: Shakespeare
LMC 3228.Description: An examination of Shakespeare's works with attention to generic conventions, historical context, and the relationship of text and performance. Major works of Shakespeare's contemporaries are studied as appropriate.

LMC 3234.Name: Fiction, Nonfiction & Memoir
LMC 3234.Description: This course explores a range of creative literary genres, and combines study and analysis of existing modes of one or more forms in order to establish a basis for original creative work by class members.

LMC 3252.Name: Fantasy TV
LMC 3252.Description: Explores in depth a theoretical issue central to film and/or television. Among its concerns are authorship, genre history, spectatorship, ideology, narrative theory, and the relationship between these media and social history.

LMC 3256.Name: Western & Asian Auteurs
LMC 3256.Description: Traces in depth an individual artist's career and affords students the opportunity to immerse themselves in the works of an important figure in the world of film.

LMC 3257.Name: Japanese Cinema
LMC 3257.Description: This course examines selected movements, styles, and trends in world cinema, emphasizing how contemporary film's global nature affects cultural representation.

LMC 3258.Name: Documentary Film
LMC 3258.Description: This course examines significant movements, styles, and trends in fact-based film, emphasizing its cultural implications and formal strategies.

LMC 3262.Name: Sports and Performance
LMC 3262.Description: An examination of cultural theories of performance and their application to the analysis of specific performative events.

LMC 3304.Name: Science, Tech & Gender
LMC 3304.Description: Examines specific philosophical, scientific, and cultural texts to determine the role that gender has played in the scientific and technological knowledge, currently and historically.

LMC 3306.Name: Science, Tech & Race
LMC 3306.Description: Examines specific historical and contemporary construction of race, within the prevailing scientific theories and ideologies in order to determine the role played by "race" in scientific and technological culture.

LMC 3318.Name: Biomedicine & Culture
LMC 3318.Description: Discuss the history of biology and medicine; popular representations of health, disease, and the medical establishment; and the cultural implications of medical imaging technologies.

LMC 3403.Name: Tech Communication
LMC 3403.Description: This course introduces students to workplace document genres to develop visual and verbal skills in critical analysis and document development.

LMC 3404.Name: Social Media
LMC 3404.Description: Students learn the cultural history, theory, and practice of social media in a variety of settings, and its impact on personal, professional, and political life.

LMC 3406.Name: Video Production
LMC 3406.Description: An introduction to video production including basic skills in storyboarding, scripting, filming, editing, and sound.

LMC 3407.Name: Advanced Video Prod
LMC 3407.Description: This production course teaches students to create visually compelling and emotionally powerful images through shot design and the use of lights, cameras and prime lenses.

LMC 3431.Name: Tech Comm Approaches
LMC 3431.Description: Part of a multi-semester sequence that students take in tandem with major-specific classes to develop professional written, visual, oral, and analytic strategies.

LMC 3504.Name: Renaisance Lit&Culture
LMC 3504.Description: An examination of literature and culture from 1450 to 1650 with an emphasis on both major achievements and divergent voices.

LMC 3511.Name: American Lit & Culture
LMC 3511.Description: Introduces students to American literature and culture broadly construed, examining foundational works of critical and historical significance.

LMC 3512.Name: Brit/Cont Romanticism
LMC 3512.Description: Examines British and Continental Romanticism as it appeared during the latter part of the eighteenth century and the first half of the nineteenth century.

LMC 3516.Name: Lit & Cultural Modernism
LMC 3516.Description: A partial investigation of the aesthetic ferment that characterizes English-language cultural production from the turn of the century to the end of World War II.

LMC 3661.Name: Theatre Production III
LMC 3661.Description: In this "hands-on" course, students will create and execute a publicity campaign and operate the box office for DramaTech Theatre productions.

LMC 3662.Name: Theatre Production IV
LMC 3662.Description: This course providess students an opportunity to perform onstage in a production at DramaTech Theatre. Auditions are required.

LMC 3705.Name: Prin Information Design
LMC 3705.Description: Presents principles and practices guiding the development of emerging digital genres. Emphasis on maximizing the affordances of the computer in organizing and communicating complex information.

LMC 3710.Name: Prin Interaction Design
LMC 3710.Description: Examines principles of design for shaping the procedural and participatory affordances of digital environments, emphasizing the role of cultural context and media transitions.

LMC 4406.Name: Professional Comm
LMC 4406.Description: Intended primarily for students planning careers in professional communication, this course will alternate among a number of issues including property law, integrating print and electronic media, and cultural studies of corporate environments.

LMC 4500.Name: Film Criticism
LMC 4500.Description: An in-depth investigation of a major movement, theory, period, or technological development in film studies.

LMC 4602.Name: Performance Practicum
LMC 4602.Description: Practical experience and theoretical investigations in theatre and performance making including acting, directing, designing, playwriting, performance art, performance and new media.

LMC 4701.Name: US Rsch Proposal Writing
LMC 4701.Description: This course is intended to guide undergraduate students from all disciplines through the stages of writing a proposal for their research option project and thesis.

LMC 4702.Name: US Rsch Thesis Writing
LMC 4702.Description: This course is intended to guide undergraduate students from all disciplines through the stages of writing their undergraduate thesis.

LMC 4710.Name: Game Studio
LMC 4710.Description: Project-based course in designing and implementing video games.

LMC 4720.Name: Interactive Narrative
LMC 4720.Description: Examines significant examples of this emerging genre, including its roots ini experimental uses of older media, and engages students in creating their own interactive narrative.

LMC 4731.Name: Game AI
LMC 4731.Description: Examines expressive possibilities of artificial intelligence techniques in computer games.

LMC 4733.Name: Mixed Reality Design
LMC 4733.Description: Project-based course in designing implementing experiences using the technologies of Augmented, Mixed, and Virtual Reality. Credit not awarded for both LMC 4733 and CS 4770/6770/LMC 6340.

LMC 4813.Name: Creative Portfolio
LMC 4813.Description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

LMC 4904.Name: Internship
LMC 4904.Description: Offers students a workplace-based learning experience that stresses application of principles and skills gained in other STAC classes.

LMC 6311.Name: Visual Culture and Desi
LMC 6311.Description: Explores visual media through a mutually instructive and integrated interplay between critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6311 and LCC 6311.

LMC 6313.Name: Prin of Interaction Desi
LMC 6313.Description: Explores visual media through a mutually instructive and integrated interplay between critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6313 and LCC 6313.

LMC 6317.Name: Interactive Fiction
LMC 6317.Description: Students create interactive fictions in a variety of formats including intersecting story worlds, interactive characters, simulations, and replay worlds. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6317 and LCC 6317, LMC 6317 and LCC 4720, or LMC 6317 and LMC 4720.

LMC 6318.Name: Experimental Media
LMC 6318.Description: Students will develop the critical, intellectual, and creative tools necessary to understand, work with, and reimagine design at the developmental stages of emerging technologies. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6318 and LCC 6318.

LMC 6325.Name: Game Design and Analysis
LMC 6325.Description: Focused topics in the theory and practice of game design, theory, and analysis, including issues of creation, and reception, such as a single sub-genre, procedural technique, or media tradition. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6325 and LCC 6325, LMC 6325 and LCC 4725, or LMC 6325 and LMC 4725.

LMC 6340.Name: Reality Experience Desi
LMC 6340.Description: This course introduces students to the design of digital experienced for education and entertainment using Augmented Reality, Tangible Computing, or other forms of Mixed Reality. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6340 and LCC 6340/LMC 4733/CS 6770/4770.

LMC 6650.Name: Project Studio
LMC 6650.Description: This course offers students the opportunity to work on focused research within existing long-term projects of the New Media(NM) Center.

LMC 6748.Name: Social Justice & Design
LMC 6748.Description: Focuses on social justice from a Science, Technology, and Society(STS) point of view that is informed by critical theory and philosophy of design. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6748 and LCC 6748 or LMC 6748 and PUBP 6748.

LMC 6800.Name: DM MS Project Course
LMC 6800.Description: Final project course in Digital Media.

LMC 6998.Name: HCI Master's Project
LMC 6998.Description: Final project for students completing a Human-Computer Interaction master's degree in the Digital Media track. Repeatable for multi-semester projects.

LMC 7000.Name: Master's Thesis
LMC 7000.Description: Final Thesis course in Digital Media.

LMC 8001.Name: Digital Media Studies
LMC 8001.Description: Advanced work in production and critique of new media forms. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 8001 and LCC 8001.

LMC 8997.Name: Teaching Assistantship
LMC 8997.Description: For graduate students holding teaching assistantships

LMC 8998.Name: Research Assistantship
LMC 8998.Description: For graduate students holding research assistantships.

LMC 8999.Name: PhD Doctoral Prep
LMC 8999.Description: Doctoral Thesis Prep in Digital Media

MGT 2106.Name: Legal Aspects-Business
MGT 2106.Description: Development and function of the law, court organization, procedure, and substantive law in contracts, business organizations, and agencies. Also exposes social responsibility and ethics in business.

MGT 2210.Name: Info Sys & Dig Transform
MGT 2210.Description: How information and information systems support business operations, decision-making, and differentiation, and transform organizations and industries. Hands-on experience with current tools for working with data.

MGT 2250.Name: Management Statistics
MGT 2250.Description: This is the introduction to basic statistics for management students.

MGT 2255.Name: Quant. Anlys. for Bus.
MGT 2255.Description: This course focuses on the problem-solving and decision-making processes that use quantitative management science concepts and techniques. Credit will not be awarded for both MGT 2255 and MGT 2251.

MGT 3000.Name: Financ & Managerial Acct
MGT 3000.Description: A foundation course in measuring and reporting the financial performance and status of the firm as well as basic concepts in cost and managerial accounting. No credit allowed for MGT majors. No credit allowed for MGT 3000 and ACCT 2101.  Credit not allowed for MGT 3000 and ACCT 2102.

MGT 3062.Name: Financial Management
MGT 3062.Description: An introduction to finance. Topics include: time value of money, capital budgeting, risk and return, capital structure, dividend policy, and working capital management. No credit allowed for MGT 3062 and MGT 3078.

MGT 3075.Name: Security Valuation
MGT 3075.Description: The valuation of securities using fundamental and technical analysis. Topics include: DCF valuation, price multiples, free cash flow, and the construction of quantitative trading models.

MGT 3076.Name: Investments
MGT 3076.Description: Introduction to the securities markets and a study of the theory and practice of security analysis and portfolio management as applied to stocks and bonds.

MGT 3078.Name: Finance & Investments
MGT 3078.Description: An introduction to finance and to the securities markets. Topics include: time value of money, risk and return, capital budgeting, security analysis and portfolio management of stocks, bonds, and derivatives. No credit allowed for MGT majors. Credit not allowed for MGT 3078 and MGT 3062.

MGT 3079.Name: Mgt of Fin Institutions
MGT 3079.Description: Introduction to the various risks faced by financial institutions and a detailed analysis of the tools used to manage these risks.

MGT 3101.Name: Organizational Behavior
MGT 3101.Description: Introduction to how the behavior of individuals, groups, and organizations affects organizational effectiveness.  Credit not allowed for both MGT 3101 and 3150.

MGT 3102.Name: Mgt Hum Res-Reg Environ
MGT 3102.Description: Analysis of various frameworks for understanding the social regulatory environments of human resources management and how they influence management decision making.

MGT 3118.Name: Cross-Cultural Mgt
MGT 3118.Description: This course develops students' global awareness to better understand and cope with the issues and challenges that managers face when working across international boundaries.

MGT 3300.Name: Marketing Management I
MGT 3300.Description: The course presents and develops the primary marketing variables that are used in designing an overall marketing program.  A systems approach is taken with the variables managed to optimize overall results.

MGT 3310.Name: Marktng Resrch Analytcs
MGT 3310.Description: This course covers the fundamentals of the analytical aspects of marketing research. The course has an applied orientation with application to contemporary issues in marketing.

MGT 3313.Name: Social Media Marketing
MGT 3313.Description: Explores the use of social media marketing as a fundamental marketing channel for driving customer engagement, brand advocacy, and enhanced customer loyalty.

MGT 3325.Name: Product Planning
MGT 3325.Description: Overviews issues inherent in product development and product management. These include product strategy, idea generation, market development, product positioning, test marketing, launch, and brand management.

MGT 3501.Name: Operations Management
MGT 3501.Description: This course focuses on the issues and techniques relevant to the management of the operations function within an organization, emphasizing its strategic significance.

MGT 3510.Name: Management of Technology
MGT 3510.Description: Focus on managing the design, assessment, and implementation-change strategy of a firm's manufacturing and information-based technological capabilities to improve competitive performance.

MGT 3599.Name: Career Develmnt Workshop
MGT 3599.Description: This workshop style class focuses on skills and strategies for identifying a career path and conducting a successful job search in the field of management.

MGT 3607.Name: Business Ethics
MGT 3607.Description: This courses introduces students to ethical aspects of the business decision-making process, including: theoretical underpinnings of ethics, stakeholders, and decision-making strategies.

MGT 3659.Name: Foundations of Strategy
MGT 3659.Description: This course covers the basic concepts and frameworks of strategy analysis and strategy formulation. Credit will not be awarded for both MGT 3659 and MGT 4195.

MGT 3660.Name: International Business
MGT 3660.Description: Examines the position of the U.S. in world markets, various types of international business transactions, and the relationship of business to global economic, political-legal and cultural forces.

MGT 3661.Name: Adv Concepts-Int'l Bus
MGT 3661.Description: Covers significant aspects of international business with a particular focus on the challenges associated with transnational corporations.

MGT 3663.Name: Technology Strategy
MGT 3663.Description: Provides an understanding of economic and strategic factors that guide firms' strategic decisions regarding the generation, commercialization, protection, and adoption of the technological innovations.

MGT 3664.Name: Corporate Strategy
MGT 3664.Description: Provides frameworks and case studies to understand how companies create value across different businesses.

MGT 3743.Name: Emerging Technologies
MGT 3743.Description: Analysis of emerging technologies and their impacts for firm practice, market practice, policy, and society.  Credit not allowed for both MGT 3743 and ME 3743 or CS 3743.

MGT 3744.Name: Mangn Prod Serv Tech Dev
MGT 3744.Description: Analysis of the managerial challenges of the product development process. Credit not allowed for both MGT 3744 and ME 3744/CS 3744.

MGT 3745.Name: Business Programming
MGT 3745.Description: An introduction to the basic concepts and skills of software programming and their applications to solving business problems.

MGT 4010.Name: Business Taxation
MGT 4010.Description: Comprehensive survey of federal taxation of business. A focus on tax planning and decision making will extend to the study of the tax code and regulations.

MGT 4015.Name: Adv Managerial Acct
MGT 4015.Description: The course will examine current issues in managerial accounting.

MGT 4026.Name: Fin Report & Analysis I
MGT 4026.Description: Intermediate-level treatment of revenue recognition, inventories, contracts, interest capitalization, property and equipment, intangibles, long-term liabilities, and shareholder's equity. Significant emphasis on financial analysis.

MGT 4029.Name: Financial Stmt Analysis
MGT 4029.Description: Students will learn to use financial statements and related data to forecast profitability, assess credit risk, model earnings quality, and estimating intrinsic value.

MGT 4041.Name: Audit&Fin Control Sys
MGT 4041.Description: This course covers professional issues surrounding auditing and financial control systems. Topics include management fraud, legal liability, audit evidence, etc.

MGT 4043.Name: Advanced Fin Reporting
MGT 4043.Description: Financial reporting and accounting for: mergers and acquisitions; consolidated financial statements; international transactions and hedges of exchange-rate fluctuations; partnerships; and governmental and not-for-profit organizations.  Credit not allowed for both MGT 4043 and MGT 6043.

MGT 4050.Name: Business Analytics
MGT 4050.Description: This course teaches the process of transforming data into business insights. It covers the methodologies, algorithms, issues, and challenges related to analyzing business data.

MGT 4052.Name: Systems Analysis& Design
MGT 4052.Description: An introductory course on the development life cycle of business information systems. It covers analysis and design tools and methodology.  Credit not allowed for both MGT 4052 and CS 4052.

MGT 4056.Name: Electronic Commerce
MGT 4056.Description: This course examines the business and technical issues related to electronic commerce applications, such as the Internet, WWW, EDI, and electronic linkages between trading partners.

MGT 4058.Name: Database Management
MGT 4058.Description: An introductory course on databases providing hands-on experience with a DBMS. Topics include data modeling, relational database design, and SQL.

MGT 4066.Name: Corporate Restructuring
MGT 4066.Description: This course examines the finance, economics, law, and business strategies that underlie major corporate restructuring transactions. Topics include valuation, acquisitions, divestitures, and high-leveraged transactions.

MGT 4067.Name: Fncl Mkts Trading&Struct
MGT 4067.Description: The course focuses on liquidity, market structure and trading.  Attention is given to the efficiency of trading systems and the role of intermediaries on market structure issues.

MGT 4068.Name: Fixed Income
MGT 4068.Description: This course covers the important securites that trade in the fixed income market and the valuation models that are used to price them.

MGT 4070.Name: International Finance
MGT 4070.Description: Financial management in an international setting.  Topics include: foreign exchange markets, exchange risk management, international portfolio investment, and foreign direct investment.

MGT 4072.Name: Entrepreneurial Finance
MGT 4072.Description: This course has been developed to expand the student's understanding and knowledge of the financial aspects of starting, funding, operating, and/or exiting an entrepreneurial venture.  Credit not allowed for both MGT 4072 and MGT 6086.

MGT 4073.Name: Financial Modeling
MGT 4073.Description: This course presents tools necessary to build advanced Excel spreadsheets for financial decision-making. The course will include topics such as firm valuation, financial statements, cost of capital, portfolio construction, option valuation, duration and immunization.

MGT 4074.Name: Fintech & Crypto Tokens
MGT 4074.Description: Digital innovation is disrupting Financial Intermediation like lending, payments, asset management, and insurance. This class gives a comprehensive understanding of the FinTech industry.

MGT 4102.Name: Management Consulting
MGT 4102.Description: This course explores being a Management Consultant, and will introduce students to consulting frameworks and methods; simulate consulting activities and situations using cases.

MGT 4189.Name: Social Impact-Exp&Design
MGT 4189.Description: This is a project-based course that is focused on system-level exploration of social issues and provides opportunities for leadership development and working in teams.

MGT 4193.Name: Serv Lead Values Systems
MGT 4193.Description: An exploration of the nature and integration of inidividual and organizational values, systemic thinking, and the concept of servant leadership.  Learning occurs through case studies, simulations, readings, personal reflection and team activities.

MGT 4194.Name: Social Entrepreneurship
MGT 4194.Description: Social Entrepreneurship applies innovative solutions to the world's pressing social problems by having students utilize leadership and managerial skills to address major challenges.

MGT 4196.Name: Strategy Consulting Prac
MGT 4196.Description: Provides experiential learning in strategy processes of analysis, design, and execution. Emphasis on issues currently confronted by major corporations.

MGT 4220.Name: Integrative Management
MGT 4220.Description: Provides understanding of strategy implementation and the integration of different functional areas of the firm using lectures, cases, and a Capstone simulation. Credit will not be awared for both MGT 4220 and MGT 4195.

MGT 4309.Name: Services Marketing
MGT 4309.Description: Explores how many of the traditional marketing models can be adapted to the marketing of services, as well as introducing entirely new concepts and frameworks specifically applicable to services and services marketing.

MGT 4311.Name: Digital Marketing
MGT 4311.Description: This course explores the various components of the digital channel including social, mobile, and search engine marketing to understand how to implement an effective digital marketing strategy.

MGT 4312.Name: Mktg Rsrch:Tools&Design
MGT 4312.Description: Explores the ways that managers design marketing research studies to solve specific marketing problems, including methodology selection, data collection, and reporting of results.

MGT 4314.Name: Understndg Mkts Data Sci
MGT 4314.Description: This course applies a data science approach using network and text analytics to model and analyze how individuals and various kinds of markets behave.

MGT 4331.Name: Consumer Behavior
MGT 4331.Description: An applied course that provides a basic understanding of the behavioral science concepts to explain the behavior of consumers in the marketplace.

MGT 4345.Name: Mrktng Consulting Pract
MGT 4345.Description: This project based course provides practical experience addressing strategic marketing opportunities and helps develop high value skills for critically analyzing problems and providing tractable solutions.

MGT 4366.Name: Service Operations Mgt
MGT 4366.Description: This course analyzes operational performance for the service and for service-support functions of manufacturers. Industries include information services, health care, parking, transportation, distribution, and retail.

MGT 4367.Name: Revenue Analytics
MGT 4367.Description: This course examines how an organization deploys and manages model and data driven pricing techniques to maximize revenues.

MGT 4401.Name: Supply Chain Modeling
MGT 4401.Description: The objective of this course is to provide students with tools and models for matching supply and demand in the most cost effective way.

MGT 4450.Name: Project Management
MGT 4450.Description: Concepts, techniques, and tools from the project management body of knowledge covering initiating, planning, controlling, executing, and closing projects. Includes agile techniques and certification preparation. Credit will not be awarded for both MGT 4450 and MGT 6450.

MGT 4667.Name: Strat Entrepreneurship
MGT 4667.Description: Provides strategic frameworks and in-depth discussions that help students navigate the entrepreneurial process and make decisions about customers, competition, and technology while dealing with uncertainty.

MGT 4670.Name: Entrepreneurship
MGT 4670.Description: Provides students with an understanding of the process of establishing a technology-based venture. Students learn how to evaluate market opportunities, conduct feasibility studies, create venture teams, and write business plans.

MGT 4725.Name: Info Security Policy
MGT 4725.Description: Information security vulnerabilities and risks; legal, cost, privacy, and technology constraints; derivation of strategies; technical and procedural means of achieving desired ends. Credit will not be awarded for both MGT 4725 and MGT 6725 or CS 6725 or CS 4725 or PUBP 4725 or PUBP 6725.

MGT 4742.Name: Tech & Mgt Cap Proj
MGT 4742.Description: Project-based course where students in the Technology and Management Program will work in inter-disciplinary teams on projects provided by corporate affiliates.  Credit not allowed for both MGT 4742 and CS 4742 or ME 4742.

MGT 4811.Name: Special Topics
MGT 4811.Description: Permits a group of students and a professor to pursue areas of management not extensively treated in other courses.

MGT 4833.Name: Healthcare Consulting Practicum
MGT 4833.Description: Permits a group of students and a professor to pursue areas of management not extensively treated in any other course.

MGT 4910.Name: Special Problems
MGT 4910.Description: Independent study conducted for one student under the guidance of a faculty member.

MGT 4911.Name: Special Problems
MGT 4911.Description: Independent study conducted for one student under the guidance of a faculty member.

MGT 4912.Name: Special Problems
MGT 4912.Description: Independent study conducted for one student under the guidance of a faculty member.

MGT 6000.Name: Financial & Mgrl Acct I
MGT 6000.Description: A foundation course in measuring and reporting the financial performance and status of the firm through financial reports and their construction, as well as basic concepts in cost and managerial accounting, valuation of assets, and revenue recognition..

MGT 6010.Name: Business Taxation
MGT 6010.Description: Comprehensive survey of federal taxation of business. A focus on tax planning and decision making will extend the study of the tax code regulations.

MGT 6015.Name: Managerial Accounting II
MGT 6015.Description: The course covers cost estimation, relevant costs, transfer pricing, capital budgeting, profitability analysis, performance evaluation, and activity-based management.

MGT 6020.Name: Fin Reporting & Analy I
MGT 6020.Description: Study of the techniques and concepts surrounding the construction of financial reports, including Intermediate-level treatment of revenue recognition, inventories, contacts, interest capitalization, property and equipment, intangibles, long-term liabilities, and shareholders' equity. Significant emphasis on financial analysis.

MGT 6029.Name: Financial Stmt Analysis
MGT 6029.Description: Students will learn to use financial statements and related data to forecast profitability, assess credit risk, model earnings quality, and estimating intrinsic value.

MGT 6030.Name: International Accounting
MGT 6030.Description: An overview of accounting techniques and concepts surrounding the construction of financial reports related to issues arising from the increased internationalization of business. Topics include comparative financial reporting among countries and accounting treatments of international transactions.

MGT 6042.Name: Audit & Fin Control Sys
MGT 6042.Description: This course covers professional issues surrounding auditing and financial control systems with a primary focus on financial statement analysis and auditor decision-making based on this analysis. Topics include management fraud, auditing standards, sampling methods, and collection of audit evidence.

MGT 6043.Name: Advanced Fin Reporting
MGT 6043.Description: Financial reporting  techniques and concepts  for mergers and acquisitions; consolidated financial statements; international transactions; partnerships; and governmental and not-for-profit financial reporting.

MGT 6056.Name: Electronic Commerce
MGT 6056.Description: This course examines the business and technical issues related to electronic commerce applications and transactions that involve the use of computer networks. The course offers insight into digital business model analysis and design.

MGT 6067.Name: Fin Commerical Real Est
MGT 6067.Description: The course will examine commercial real estate assets from two perspectives: the unique nature of the financing and ownership structures and their role as an asset class in investment portfolios. Students will build financial models to mathematically analyze the impact of these different structures on required returns and portfolio diversification.

MGT 6070.Name: International Finance
MGT 6070.Description: Financial management in an international setting. Topics include: international financial markets such as foreign exchange spot and derivatives markets, international economics (trade, balance of payments), forecasting exchange rates with statistical models, exchange risk management using financial models, international stock and bond markets, and international portfolio management.

MGT 6076.Name: Valuing Technology Firms
MGT 6076.Description: The course involves valuing technology firms using the relative methods, discounted cash flow method and real options useful in mergers, acquisitions, and IPOs.

MGT 6080.Name: Investments
MGT 6080.Description: Introduction to securities markets and study of theory and practice of security analysis and portfolio management concepts as applied to equities and fixed-income securities. Portfolio management relies on probability theory, statistical analysis, and computational methods. Credit not allowed for MGT 6078 and MGT 6080.

MGT 6081.Name: Derivative Securities
MGT 6081.Description: An introduction to mathematical models used to price options, futures, and swaps is provided. Concepts of arbitrage, index trading, and portfolio insurance are discussed.

MGT 6083.Name: Real Estate Practicum
MGT 6083.Description: Designed for graduate students with an interest in real estate. It consists of a one semester case study for a specific company or competitive program.

MGT 6110.Name: Negotiation and Conflict
MGT 6110.Description: This course covers the theory and process of negotiation and conflict resolution as it is practiced in different settings. Students develop understanding of other parties’ interests and perspectives, personality, and conflict management styles, and learn to build effective relationships.

MGT 6113.Name: NonProfit Team Cons Proj
MGT 6113.Description: Teams work on a project developed in consultation with a not for profit organization, and present results to organizations and boards.

MGT 6118.Name: Cross-Cultural Mgt
MGT 6118.Description: This course develops students' global awareness to better understand and cope with the issues and challenges that managers face when working across international boundaries.

MGT 6119.Name: Leading Teams
MGT 6119.Description: This course prepares students to be an effective leader and manager of teams by giving students frameworks to implement and diagnose effective team processes.

MGT 6197.Name: Global Strategic Mgt
MGT 6197.Description: This course provides a forum for the analysis of managerial and organizational demands associated with effectively competing in global industries. Students will learn strategic concepts, analytical frameworks, and heuristics for taking strategic decisions in the global context, such where to compete around the globe, which products and services to offer in which locations, where to locate business operations, and how to organize and effectively coordinate global activities

MGT 6203.Name: Data  Analytics Business
MGT 6203.Description:
This course teaches the scientific process of transforming data into insights for
making better business decisions. The use of examples places business analytics techniques in context and teaches students how to avoid the common pitfalls, emphasizing the importance of building proper models.

MGT 6213.Name: Bus Analytics Managers
MGT 6213.Description: This course covers the models, issues, and challenges of business analytics. Students develop business analytics models to business problems and understand the models’ outputs.

MGT 6302.Name: Consumer Behavior
MGT 6302.Description: This course exposes students to fundamental concepts and approaches from the behavioral sciences that can be used to understand, predict, and influence.

MGT 6304.Name: Customer Relationshp Mgt
MGT 6304.Description: Provides an understanding of analytic techniques and computer models in analyzing customer-centric data and developing customer relationship management (CRM) strategy.

MGT 6307.Name: Integrated Mktg Comm
MGT 6307.Description: An exploration of frameworks, processes, and tools used by organizations to develop and sustain effective marketing communications, with an emphasis on emerging communication channels.

MGT 6310.Name: Marketing Resrch: Analytics
MGT 6310.Description: This course covers the fundamentals of the analytical aspects of marketing research. The course has an applied orientation with application to contemporary issues in marketing.

MGT 6311.Name: Digital Marketing
MGT 6311.Description: An applied overview of modernized digital marketing tools and strategy, emphasizing the diverse ways that contemporary marketers use information technology through digital channels such as social media and the Internet to achieve strategic business objectives.

MGT 6314.Name: Understndg Mkts  Data Sci
MGT 6314.Description: This course applies a data science approach using network and text analytics to model and analyze how individuals and various kinds of markets behave.

MGT 6326.Name: Collaborative Prod Dev
MGT 6326.Description: Introduction to product development and product management topics through management science techniques and statistical analysis. These include product strategy, idea generation, experiment design, market development, managing product portfolios and positioning, testing of prototype systems, and brand management.

MGT 6352.Name: International Practicum
MGT 6352.Description: A project-based course that provides an opportunity to apply decisions under uncertainty in global environments in the context of real and practical international business problems.

MGT 6359.Name: Bus Str Sustainability
MGT 6359.Description: Introduces business strategies such as eco-efficiency, product stewardship, green marketing and sustainable development. Cases, speakers reflect current issues such as electronics waste and global warming.

MGT 6369.Name: Sustainabl Bus Practicum
MGT 6369.Description: Students work on real-world consulting projects focused on sustainability related challenge for companies, non-profits, and/or government organizations.

MGT 6400.Name: Pricing Analytics & Rev
MGT 6400.Description: Focus in on increasing profit by measuring price responses and controlling capacity.  Topics include forecasting, price optimization, and revenue management.  Credit not allowed for both MGT 6400 and MGT 6362.

MGT 6401.Name: Supply Chain Modeling
MGT 6401.Description: Focus on the design and implementation of succesful supply chain strategies. Develop and recommend the right mix of operational levers  through quantitative analysis for supply chain efficiency and effectiveness. Topics include: supply chain design, supply chain coordination, capacity management, retailing, and supplier management. Credit not allowed for both MGT 6401 and MGT 6362.

MGT 6405.Name: Lean Six Sigma
MGT 6405.Description: This class will explore the DMAIC model, lean tools and how data analysis can be leveraged to solve real world problems.

MGT 6450.Name: Project Management
MGT 6450.Description: Provides exposure to the concepts, frameworks and techniques for managing projects. Coverage includes both general project management frameworks along with agile methodologies commonly used to manage IT projects. Cases, problems, activities, software tools, extra readings, and guest speakers focus specifically on IT project management practice.

MGT 6452.Name: Machine Learning for Bus
MGT 6452.Description: This course introduces machine learning techniques and their applications in solving business problems. It covers core concepts, algorithm designs, and programming implementation with business

MGT 6500.Name: Analytic Tools/Decisions
MGT 6500.Description: Introduction to the most commonly use statistical and optimization-based analytical tools for data-based decision-making based on the data available, including  descriptive statistics, probability and distributions, hypothesis testing, and regression.

MGT 6503.Name: Managing Info Resources
MGT 6503.Description: Focuses on emerging trends and business models in organizational information technology infrastructure, the information technology industry, and the tools to manage the information resources in an organization through techniques related to data management, analytics, and visualization.

MGT 6504.Name: Principles of Finance
MGT 6504.Description: Mathematic principles of finance including time value of money, risk and return relationship, capital budgeting. Credit will not be awarded for both MGT 6504 and MGT 6060.

MGT 6506.Name: Managerial Economics
MGT 6506.Description: Microeconomics is about scarcity and how individuals make choices in the face of scarcity. Topics include suppy/demand, markets and price system, risk/uncertainty, market limitations. Credit will not be awarded for both MGT 6506 and MGT 6130.

MGT 6507.Name: Business Communications
MGT 6507.Description: The purpose of this course is to provide future leaders and managers with the communication skills that enable them to sell themselves and their ideas. Credit will not be awarded for both MGT 6507 and MGT 6127.

MGT 6508.Name: Strategic Management
MGT 6508.Description: Strategic management builds on and integrates other functional core courses to understand how firms gain and sustain a competitive advantage. Credit will not be awarded for both MGT 6508 and MGT 6125 or MGT 6508 and MGT 6126.

MGT 6509.Name: Legal & Ethical Business
MGT 6509.Description: Constitutional law; dispute resolution; torts; contracts; theories of ethical analysis; and the role of stakeholders. Credit will not be awarded for both MGT 6509 and MGT 6124 or MGT 6509 and MGT 6126.

MGT 6510.Name: Leadership Development
MGT 6510.Description: This course focuses on how to lead individuals and teams within organizations and will develop a systematic understanding of behavior within formal organizational settings.

MGT 6518.Name: Strategy Fundamentals
MGT 6518.Description: This course covers concepts and frameworks for strategy analysis and formulation. Strategic management integrates perspectives to understand how firms gain and sustain competitive advantage.

MGT 6655.Name: Business Data Prep & Viz
MGT 6655.Description: This course helps business graduate students learn how to prepare and visualize data appropriately, to explore patterns and relations, and to convey these findings effectively.

MGT 6663.Name: Technology Strategy
MGT 6663.Description: Provides an understanding of economic and strategic factors that guide firms' strategic decisions regarding generation, commercialization, protection, and adoption of technological innovations.

MGT 6667.Name: Strat Entrepreneurship
MGT 6667.Description: Provides a strategic perspective on the entrepreneurial process, competition and strategic interactions between startups and incumbents, cooperation and open innovation strategies.

MGT 6725.Name: Info Security Policies
MGT 6725.Description: Information security vulnerabilities and risks; legal, cost, privacy, and technology constraints; derivation of strategies; technical and procedural means of achieving desired ends. Credit will not be awarded for both MGT 6725 and MGT 4725 or CS 4725 or CS 6725 or PUBP 4725 or PUBP 6725.

MGT 6727.Name: Privacy for Professionals
MGT 6727.Description: This course takes a multi-disciplinary approach to the study of privacy––a current topic of international interest for those in technology, policy, law, and/or business.

MGT 6748.Name: Appld Analytics Pract
MGT 6748.Description: Practical analytics project experience applying ideas from the classroom to a significant project of interest to a business, government agency, or other organization.
